entry.title: Juhi Kulshreshtha
entry.content:
Juhi {juhik2003}

  • India
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Juhi in LinkedIn

Juhi is a Senior SAP Professional with more than 20 years of experience in implementation, operations and support of business technology in various areas of SAP. In her current role, she is leading SAP BTP Practice in her organisation and is responsible for growing SAP BTP Competencies. She is responsible for making sure that the BTP developments are aligned with the Best Practices recommended by SAP. Also to make sure that BTP teams leverage the finest methodologies and reference architectures. Her role also includes evangelizing about the ‘Art of Possible’ in BTP within the organisation and to clients. Her current areas of focus also include Custom AI/ML solutions, GenAI and Business AI in SAP. Her latest area of interest is BDC and how to leverage BDC to gain business insights. She believes in constant learning and upskilling and encourages her teams to stay updated with latest skills and tools.

She is an active member of SAP Community and an avid blogger. She has participated as a speaker in multiple SAP Inside Track Events in India, Podcasts and Virtual Roundtables during the last 2 years. She is an SAP BTP evangelist and loves to share her knowledge about BTP and AI/ML.

Topics of interest: BTP, AI/ML, GenAI, BDC

Juhi, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

After working for over 20 years in SAP areas, I have encountered numerous challenges and questions raised by clients, analysts, and developers who implement SAP solutions. My teams and I have often provided innovative solutions to these issues. However, without a broader platform to share this knowledge, much of this valuable experience has remained within our organizations.

I am also inspired by the other SAP Mentors and the significant value they contribute to the SAP ecosystem.

As an SAP Mentor, I would like to share knowledge and learn from others’ experiences in this ecosystem. It is a fantastic platform for the cross-pollination of ideas and innovative outcomes. I would be delighted if I could improve the life of even a single developer or client through this process and give back to the wonderful SAP community.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

My advice to other SAP Community members is to always be curious about learning new technologies in SAP. Ask yourself: Why am I implementing a particular SAP technology? Am I able to bring value to the table and provide a great experience for my stakeholders? What kind of impact is my code making ?  You will find that these questions are the triggers where your real learning journey will start. And that’s how I started mine.

entry.title: Episode 33: DevOps in BTP with CI/CD and cTMS service
entry.content:
In this video, the focus is on the transport management service in BTP, detailing the integration of development, acceptance, and production environments. It covers the use of cloud CI/CD services to deploy applications, manage code, and trigger automated deployments to different environments. The process involves pushing code to a Git repository, which triggers deployment in the development environment, followed by deployment to acceptance and production through the transport management service. The process can be managed by a release manager with different authorizations, alerts, and automation tools to ensure smooth deployment and scaling.

Takeaways

  • Development involves using business application studio (build code) for application development.
  • Build code or business application studio is only required for development.
  • Transport management service is used in combination with the CI/CD service to deploy applications across different sub-accounts.
  • Code is pushed to a Git repository, which triggers the CI/CD service using webhooks to deploy the application to the development account.
  • If the deployment to development is successful, the application is uploaded to the transport management service for further deployment.
  • Transport management allows deployment to acceptance and production, with controlled release processes managed by the release manager.
  • Authorization control can restrict access so that only specific roles, like administrators, can release to production, while others can release to acceptance.
  • Alerts and notifications can be set up to inform users if any issues arise during deployment.
  • Automation Pilot can be used to manage resources, like scaling memory during deployment, to prevent system bottlenecks.
  • CI/CD service could be considered within the development account for enhanced build code functionalities when they're in the same sub-account.
  • The landscape consists of different sub-accounts (development, acceptance, and production) to streamline application development and administration.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q2-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment
  • Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates
  • Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER
  • Simplified Data Integration
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Catena-X Certification
  • SAP Innovation Award Wins: Harting and Matsumoto Precision
  • Customer Success Story: DMK
  • SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

 

Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment

When integrating SAP Sustainability Footprint Management with various SAP systems, you often face a data challenge: Your warehouse in one SAP solution might be a facility in another or even a resource elsewhere. This inconsistency complicates footprint calculations, energy flow modeling, and linking environmental results to financials.

To address this and streamline and simplify the management of location data, we released the new Manage Locations application. This app serves as a single source for managing all locations, regardless of origin or business context. It addresses the need to reconcile and correlate locations that may have different semantics across multiple SAP solutions. With this new app you can:

  • View and manage all locations in one consolidated interface
  • Manually create locations or view those imported from other SAP modules
  • Easily distinguish between manually created and imported locations via the user interface
  • Navigate via links between imported location records and their corresponding system-generated system entries

Alternatively to replicating locations from source systems or creating them manually, you can upload location information via Excel files in the Import Master Data app. When importing, the software automatically generates corresponding location records that appear in the Manage Locations app – ensuring no duplicated or orphaned records. The locations itself are categorized into different location types, adding business context: Meter, Process Infrastructure, and Facility. Imported locations are automatically mapped to one of these three types. If a location type doesn’t match, it defaults to Facility. For modeling energy flows, you can now use these harmonized locations and resources as elements in your models. Hence, the creation of meters, process infrastructures, and facilities within the Model Energy Flows app is now managed exclusively via the new Manage Locations app – ensuring data consistency across apps.

Another major improvement is the possibility to assign cost centers for financial transparency and connecting carbon footprint results directly with your financial reporting. These assignments are time-dependent, ensuring correct mapping for each period. After calculating your organizational footprint, the Manage Footprint Results app shows the active cost center for that location – specifically, the cost center that is valid as of the calculation period’s start date, which is important if multiple cost centers are assigned to the location. Besides locations, cost centers can now also be assigned to energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. This enables better tracking of spending related to energy use and maintenance, helping to analyze and manage energy costs more effectively.

Click the picture to start the video:

Manage Locations App (Click to start video)

To summarize, these enhancements bring you a centralized, consistent interface for all location data with improved usability and a simplified integration across various SAP systems. The flexible cost center assignment enables the linkage of environmental data to financial entities. This empowers smarter and holistic decision-making in sustainability management, moving further along the journey towards ledger-based carbon accounting with SAP Green Ledger. For all details, see Manage Locations on SAP Help.

 

Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates

A common challenge for calculating Scope 1 and 2 emissions is the timely availability of energy bills needed for accurately recording energy consumption. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management addresses this by introducing more flexibility in how energy data can be captured. Now, when creating energy sources, you can select your preferred method for recording energy consumption, with the two available options:

  • Actual Consumption from Energy Bills: Enter the actual quantities consumed as detailed on your energy bills (the most accurate method).
  • Estimates via Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates: Add up amounts based on assigned meter readings and planned energy consumption rates, which allows you to work with estimates when bills are unavailable.

Select Recording of Energy Consumption

This new functionality isn’t limited to newly created energy sources. You can apply it to existing ones as well. However, it’s important to note that updating an energy source with this new logic doesn’t automatically trigger updates across all footprint inventories. If you edit the inventories that reference the updated energy source in their energy flow models, the system will recalculate using the newly selected consumption recording logic.

This release gives you the flexibility to maintain complete and more timely energy consumption records, improving the reliability of your sustainability data even when actual energy bills are delayed or not available at all. For more information, see the Energy Sources section under Model Energy Flows.

 

Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER

For calculating carbon footprints with no actual supplier or provider data available, it’s crucial to have access to reliable industry average data from Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) databases. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management provides you with the flexibility to upload respective data from any source into the Manage Emission Factors app. To simplify the setup for you and reduce manual efforts, we now added new default content, available for mapping your activities for calculating the respective footprints.

The data from UK Department for Energy Security and Net Zero and UK Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (UK DEFRA) includes emission factors for energy use, water consumption, waste disposal, recycling, and transport activities. There are datasets available for the years 2015 to 2024.

EMBER, an independent energy think tank, provides emission factors for electricity generation for over 200 geographies. The datasets comprise the years 2015 to 2023.

Click the picture to start the video:

Default Emission Factors in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Click to start video)

With those enhancements, you have access to additional reliable and diverse data sources for better environmental impact analysis and decision-making. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data.

This new content complements the datasets from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) which were already added last year. And for the second half year we plan to add even more pre-configured emission factors from additional sources, further enhancing your carbon footprint calculation. The addition of emission factors was also one of the highest voted items on SAP Influence, requested by several customers and partners. Thanks to your valuable feedback, we’re constantly improving our product.

 

Simplified Data Integration

SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduced significant enhancements to how sustainability data is imported and managed, making processes more simple, efficient, and user-friendly. The tool leverages the sustainability data integration service to streamline data import from SAP systems, including SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Environment, Health and Safety Management. This update eliminates many manual steps and unifies the process across systems. All changes are reflected in the updated SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Implementation Guide on SAP Help Portal.

With those enhancements, we’re also introducing the Manage Replications application. This new app allows you to configure and manage the replication of master data objects, such as products or suppliers, from multiple integrated SAP systems. Once replication is initiated through this app, imported data becomes visible in the Import Master Data app, simplifying subsequent data management tasks. The key benefits for you are:

  • Multi-source replication: Import master data from various source systems (for example fetch Products from SAP S/4HANA and Suppliers from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  • Centralized management: Oversee and control all data replications from one place.
  • Improved data consistency: Ensures data is harmonized and consistent, provided the correct source systems are chosen for each data object.
  • Filter records: For some of the entities, like Products, you can filter the source data objects so only the ones which are relevant in your footprint calculation are replicated.

To use the Manage Replications app, users must be manually assigned the roles: SUS_Replication_Viewer or SUS_Replication_Expert. Find further information as well as all details on the new app in SAP Help: Manage Replications.

Manage Replications App

For existing customers, the following changes are required:

  • Switch to Manage Replications App: The previous method of importing master data directly within the Import Master Data app is discontinued for integrated source systems. The Import button has been removed, and all such imports must now be managed through the new Manage Replications app.
  • SAP EHS Management Integration: All emissions management activities and locations must now be imported via the Manage Replications app.
  • Replication Details: When replicating Suppliers or Emission Management Activities, each replication now performs a complete import – incremental or delta updates are no longer supported for these entities.

Those updates vastly improve the efficiency and governance of sustainability data management within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, offering you a more powerful, secure, and streamlined experience when handling master data from multiple integrated sources.

 

Other Release Highlights

The Monitor Plausibility Checks app displays reference details of the item, period, and measure value used as the baseline for creating relative plausibility alerts. This helps you assess how much actual results deviate from expected calculations. For more information, see Monitor Plausibility Checks. This is also a feature that was implemented after numerous customers requested it via SAP Influence.

A new Generate Records button in the Manage Purchased Products Footprints app allows you to manually generate records for purchased products and product groups that lack footprints. Progress is displayed during record generation, and users are notified if records need to be regenerated due to data updates, ensuring accuracy and control. Additionally, the UI in the related tabs now labels the AI-assisted mapping button as Generate Mappings Using AI. See Manage Purchased Product Footprints for more details.

We achieved significant performance improvements in cycle calculations, where a process's output becomes its own input. Previously, the runtime increased with the cycle's complexity. Now, calculations are done in-memory rather than relying on database access, greatly reducing calculation time and improving user efficiency.

SAP now offers real-time machine translation for documentation on the SAP Help Portal, including SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This increases the number of available languages, improving accessibility and availability of product information for users worldwide.

To help you with onboarding and using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we’re also constantly enhancing the product documentation on SAP Help. In the previous quarter, this included the following topics:

  • Energy carrier assignment per internal service confirmation: The new topic in the Energy Distribution Scenarios section explains two different methods for assigning energy to production documents using data from internal service confirmations, see Energy Carrier Assignment per Internal Service Confirmation.
  • Modeling consistent energy flows: Useful guidance on using energy elements in flow models and explanations on how different components are connected, see Modeling Consistent Energy Flows.
  • Energy distribution scenarios: The updated explanation details how energy consumption and distribution are modeled via the energy flows, using planned rates, meter data, or both, see Energy Distribution Scenarios.
  • Importing master data for Products using file upload: An example explains how to enter data for quantity conversions and quantity dimensions, see the section Example: Quantity Conversions and Dimensions in Products.
  • Data Inconsistencies: Guidelines on addressing these issues, see Business Transaction Data Consistency for details.
  • Delete imported business transaction data: More details on how to handle this process, see Deleting Business Transaction Data.

 

Catena-X Certification

In Q2, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management successfully was Catena-X certified by Cofinity-X, as the first carbon calculation software to receive this certification. Catena-X is the automotive industry’s open, collaborative data ecosystem, designed to facilitate secure and standardized data exchange across the entire value chain. With this certification, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management meets the rigorous calculation, interoperability, and data sovereignty standards required by Catena-X, enabling customers to seamlessly calculate and share trustworthy carbon footprint and sustainability data with partners, suppliers, and customers in the ecosystem. This not only supports regulatory and customer-driven transparency requirements but also paves the way for scalable decarbonization efforts in the automotive industry and beyond. By aligning with Catena-X, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management empowers organizations to participate confidently in cross-company sustainability initiatives within a rapidly evolving digital value network. With the integration to SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, carbon footprint data can be exchanged automatically and seamlessly.

 

Innovation Award Wins

We’re very proud to announce that two of our SAP Sustainability Footprint Management customers won the SAP Innovation Award 2025 in the Sustainability Hero category: Harting Technology Group and Matsumoto Precision!

Faced with the challenge of calculating carbon footprints for over 100,000 products across 14 factories, HARTING Technology Group needed a scalable, integrated solution. By becoming an early pilot customer of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, HARTING automated emissions tracking and achieved one-click carbon footprint calculations for 13,000 products – replacing a manual, time-consuming process. The solution, now live in three factories and expanding to all 14 by 2026, enables real-time, granular CO₂ data that supports HARTING’s “GreenLine” product label and helps meet stringent EU regulations like the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) and the Digital Product Passport. Thanks to this innovation, HARTING can now report that 85% of its packaging materials are recycled, and it has a clear path to achieving net-zero operations by 2030. This collaboration with SAP not only enhances transparency and compliance but also gives HARTING a competitive edge in customer bids – proving that sustainability and business success go hand in hand. Read the whole story here: HARTING - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

To address the growing demand for carbon transparency and operational efficiency, Matsumoto Precision implemented SAP S/4HANA alongside SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This combination gave the company real-time visibility into both product-level carbon emissions and profitability. With this data-driven approach, Matsumoto Precision was able to reduce its annual CO₂ emissions by 400 tons, increase productivity by 30 percent, and improve its operating profit margin by 3 percent. The factory now runs entirely on renewable energy, with on-site solar generation covering a significant portion of its needs. The implementation also empowered employees with real-time insights, leading to better decision-making and increased job satisfaction. Customers now receive verified carbon footprint data for each product, enhancing trust and supporting their own sustainability goals. In collaboration with Accenture, Matsumoto Precision even developed a generative AI tool that automates lifecycle flow diagrams, significantly reducing manual effort and streamlining emissions reporting. As CEO Toshitada Matsumoto put it, “With SAP S/4HANA and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we make smarter, greener decisions while tracking and visualizing CO₂ emissions for each product. And with this clarity, we can enhance our brand value.” Matsumoto Precision’s journey is a compelling example of how small and mid-sized manufacturers can lead the way in sustainable innovation by embedding carbon intelligence into every layer of their operations. Read the full story here: Matsumoto Precision Co., Ltd. - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

 

Customer Success Story: DMK

Germany’s largest dairy cooperative, DMK Deutsches Milchkontor GmbH, is leading the way in sustainable food production. Processing over 5.3 billion kilograms of milk annually, DMK is committed to reducing its environmental impact across the value chain. With ambitious climate goals – including a 42% reduction in Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2030 – DMK turned to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to bring transparency and precision to its carbon accounting.

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, DMK transformed how it calculates and manages product-level emissions. The solution enabled the company to move beyond industry averages and instead use granular, actual data to assess the carbon footprint of its milk-based products. This shift provided DMK with unprecedented transparency and accuracy, particularly in understanding and reporting Scope 3 emissions from its upstream value chain, such as milk production and transportation.

The digitalization of carbon footprint management not only helped DMK meet regulatory requirements but also strengthened its ability to respond to customer demands for credible, verifiable sustainability metrics. With SAP’s expert support and a tailored pilot program, DMK integrated emissions data directly into its product lifecycle, enabling more strategic decision-making and targeted decarbonization efforts.

This collaboration has positioned DMK as a leader in sustainable dairy production, demonstrating how digital tools can drive real progress toward climate goals while enhancing trust and transparency across the value chain. Read the full story here: DMK: Identifying the carbon footprint of milk-based products on the way to decarbonizing the value chain.

 

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

SAP’s commitment to sustainability is integrated into its core mission of improving economic, social, and environmental outcomes while respecting planetary and human rights boundaries. SAP is actively using its own sustainability software solutions to meet environmental and social goals, demonstrating an “SAP runs SAP” and “customer zero” approach. By implementing tools like SAP Green Ledger, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management within its operations, SAP treats sustainability management with the same rigor as financial reporting.

As a user, SAP faces challenges similar to its clients: collecting and managing large volumes of sustainability data, ensuring compliance with evolving regulations, and integrating data systems across the organization and supply chain. By implementing its sustainability solutions and continuously refining them through hands-on experience, SAP gains valuable insights that help improve its products for clients. Key lessons from their internal adoption include: ensuring consistent emissions data collection, grounding projects within governance frameworks, expanding focus beyond carbon to other environmental factors, and establishing a multi-layer data architecture for effective collection, processing, and reporting. The rollout of these systems is iterative, enabling refinement and adaptation—especially important as regulatory requirements change, such as the new EU Omnibus package. Overall, SAP aims to provide actionable sustainability insights, streamline ESG reporting, and drive both internal and customer progress toward measurable sustainability outcomes. To learn more, read the news article from Matthias Medert, SAP’s global head of Sustainability: SAP Runs Its Own Solutions for Sustainability Goals.

A central piece of the SAP runs SAP Sustainability IT architecture is SAP Sustainability Footprint Management:

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability - IT Architecture

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP has created a centralized and integrated platform to collect and calculate its corporate carbon emissions. The ambition is clear: to achieve full coverage of SAP’s carbon footprint through automated data collection and calculation. The software is much more than just a reporting tool, it acts as a central hub for emissions data, feeding into other SAP sustainability solutions such as the SAP Green Ledger, the SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and various internal systems. This enables comprehensive environmental impact analysis and supports regulatory compliance, while also informing strategic business decisions. Currently, SAP has already validated around 50% of its corporate carbon footprint within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This includes emissions from its own facilities like offices and data centers, as well as from shared infrastructure, cloud providers, and purchased goods and services.

The journey hasn’t been without challenges. At the outset, SAP faced difficulties in gathering and harmonizing data from multiple sources, each managed by different internal teams. Some of the data also required enrichment to be usable for sustainability purposes. However, through close collaboration between internal IT and business units, these hurdles were largely overcome, resulting in a more consistent and unified data flow.

Looking ahead, SAP aims to expand the system’s coverage to 100% of its corporate carbon footprint (excluding downstream emissions) before the planned business go-live in Q3. This milestone will involve five company codes and marks a significant step toward embedding sustainability deeper into SAP’s operations. All of this is being achieved through a continuous co-innovation process with SAP’s sustainability product engineering teams, demonstrating how SAP isn’t only building tools for others but also using them to lead by example. For all details, read the paper SAP runs SAP Sustainability: How to unlock the Power of Data on Sustainability Goals at Scale.

 

Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

The new Learning Journey Establishing the Product Carbon Footprint with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is the first one that focuses on Product Carbon Footprint (PCF) calculation. The one-hour self-learning is as all our Learning Journeys free of charge and targets consultants and business users with advanced product knowledge. It explains distributing Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions to products via various methods and covers how to use the energy flow model and planned consumption rates for Scope 1 and 2, as well as additional allocation schemes for Scope 3 emissions. By completing this journey, users will be able to calculate and allocate emissions from business activities, energy use, and resources to products, leveraging dedicated models and production documents. You’ll also earn a Record of Achievement and a digital badge after successful completion and passing all quizzes.

Learning Journey: Establishing the Product Carbon Footprint with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

This new PCF-centric Learning Journey complements our existing courses focusing on CCF calculation for beginners (Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Simple Configuration) and intermediates (Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations).

 

Additional Information

To get more insights about the integration between SAP S/4HANA, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, and SAP Green Ledger, you should check out the blog post Where finance and carbon unite by @PreethaB. With a practical example, she explains how to track carbon throughout business processes and incorporate sustainability into operations. By showing the complete workflow, it’s demonstrated how integrated solutions provide valuable sustainability insights, support informed decision-making, help achieve sustainability goals, and improve operations.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: CAP just got faster: What’s new in cds-caching 1.0
entry.content:
Caching is a proven strategy to boost performance in (cloud-based) applications, especially when working with slow remote services, repetitive queries, or expensive computations. For developers building applications and services with the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), the open-source cds-caching plugin offers a powerful, flexible, and easy-to-integrate solution for application-level caching. Last week at reCAP 2025, I had the opportunity to introduce some of the new features of cds-caching 1.0 live on stage and I am happy to announce that version 1.0 has now been published. This post includes a summary of what has changed.

If you’re new to the project, check out the original introduction and deep dive on SAP Community, where I explained the motivation, architecture, and use cases in detail.

What’s New in cds-caching 1.0 ?

New Read-Through API: cache.rt.*

While cds-caching already supported read-through caching from the beginning, version 1.0 extends the functionality and clearly separates between read-aside and read-through. With read-through, the caching service automatically handles lookups and population. You just call a method like cache.rt.run() and get the result, whether from cache or freshly fetched. This contrasts with the read-aside pattern, where developers manually need to check and update the cache, leading to more boilerplate code. So read-through offers less code, better maintainability, and built-in observability.
Available methods under cache.rt:

  • run() – Wraps CQN queries and requests sent via srv.run (see CAP docs)

  • send() – Wraps service calls sent via srv.send (see CAP docs)

  • exec() – Wraps function execution

  • wrap() – General-purpose caching

Each method returns not only the result, but additional read-through data::

{
  result,      // your cached data
  cacheKey,    // the generated cache key
  metadata     // cache hit/miss, TTL info, etc.
}

The old methods (cache.run(), cache.send(), etc.) are now deprecated and will be removed in a future release.

Before:

const result = await cache.run(...);

After:

const { result } = await cache.rt.run(...);

More transparent Key Management

Cache keys are now handled the same way across all operations to ensure consistency. 

Context Awareness is Opt-In

User, tenant, and locale context are no longer only included request-based cache keys by default. They  can be enabled globally or per-operation, allowing for more control over cache key granularity. Enable context globally in your configuration, if your application supports data for different users, locales and/or multi-tenancy:

{
  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "caching": {
        //...
        "keyManagement": {
          "isUserAware": true,
          "isTenantAware": false,
          "isLocaleAware": true
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

The default behavior can be overridden individually for each cache operation by providing a placeholder string:

await cache.rt.run(query, db, { key: "mykey:{tenant}:{user}:{locale}:{hash}" });

Comprehensive Metrics & Monitoring

cds-caching 1.0 brings a new level of transparency and control to a caching strategy with a comprehensive metrics and monitoring system. It is possible to track both real-time and historical cache performance, analyze usage patterns at the key level, and fine-tune monitoring settings on the fly. Key Features:

  • Real-Time Metrics: Instantly monitor cache hit/miss rates, operation throughput, and latency to quickly assess cache health and effectiveness.
  • Historical Analytics: Persist and review metrics over time (hourly, daily, etc.) to identify trends, spot anomalies, and optimize cache configuration.
  • Key-Level Analytics: Drill down into individual cache keys to see which data is accessed most, which keys are underperforming, and how specific queries or requests behave.
  • Runtime Configuration: Enable or disable metrics collection at runtime, without restarting your application, for flexible monitoring and minimal overhead.

Tracked KPIs include:

  • Hit Ratio: Percentage of requests served from cache (higher is better).
  • Miss Ratio: Percentage of requests resulting in a cache miss.
  • Average Hit Latency: Time to serve a cache hit (should be very low).
  • Average Miss Latency: Time to fetch and cache a value after a miss.
  • Throughput: Number of cache operations per second.
  • Error Rate: Percentage of cache operations that result in errors.
  • Cache Efficiency: Ratio of miss latency to hit latency, showing the performance gain from caching.

With these insights, it is possible to continuously or selectively monitor, analyze, and optimize a caching approach.

Integrated OData-API

cds-caching 1.0 features a fully integrated OData API, making all (basic) cache operations and metrics accessible via standard HTTP endpoints. This enables seamless integration with external monitoring tools, dashboards, and custom admin UIs.  Features of the OData API:

  • Query cache statistics and key-level metrics for real-time and historical analysis.
  • List, inspect, or clear cache entries directly from your monitoring tool or admin interface.
  • Enable or disable metrics collection and adjust runtime configuration remotely.

The OData API can easily be access via custom application (see next section) for SAP Fiori Elements.

Example Application & Dashboard

A new example CAP application and UI5-based dashboard are included for hands-on learning and real-time cache monitoring. It shows the usage of the OData API as well as the key metrics.

  • Backend Application: Demonstrates annotation-based and programmatic caching patterns.
  • Dashboard: Visualizes cache metrics, key analytics, and historical data.

See the full Example Application Guide on GitHub →

Improved TypeScript Support

cds-caching 1.0 provides full TypeScript definitions for all APIs, making it easier and safer to use in TypeScript-enabled CAP projects.

import { CachingService } from 'cds-caching';
const cache = await cds.connect.to('caching') as CachingService;
const { result } = await cache.rt.run(query, db);

CAP v8 an CAP v9 support with enhanced quality

entry.title: Joule Studio Goes Live: Answers to Your Top Questions
entry.content:
We’re thrilled to announce that Joule Studio is now GA, allowing you to deliver a tailored, agentic AI experience for your enterprise. As we go live today, you likely have questions about what the product is about, how to get started, and what to expect next. To make your journey easier, I have put together this FAQ blog that addresses the most common questions we have received from our early adopters and during the webinar.  Whether you are just exploring or ready to dive in, you will find your answers here! 

 

Product overview:  

Q: What is Joule Studio? 

A: Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and AI agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency. 

Q: Who is Joule Studio for? 

A: Joule Studio is designed for developers who are seeking to innovate and create intelligent, conversational experiences with Joule, SAP’s AI co-pilot.  

Q: What makes Joule Studio different in the competitive landscape?  

A: Joule Studio delivers custom Joule agents and skills that are deeply grounded in business processes and data, ensuring reliable outcomes specific to your business.  

Agents delivered through standalone AI tools do not scale well in a heterogenous environment, breaking automation flows and end user experience. Joule Studio equips customers with an open and extensible framework that connects not only SAP but also non-SAP systems and models. That enables agents and skills to scale and execute efficiently.  

Security is the top concern for any enterprise, and Joule Studio delivers that. Developers can leverage built-in security and privacy enforcement, such as data masking and data filtering, to ensure compliance with AI interactions.  

Joule Studio delivers most business focused agents and skills that together extend Joule and drive business efficiency.  

Q: What are the key capabilities of Joule Studio? 

A: SAP Build empowers customers to expand Joule’s capabilities and adapt them to diverse business needs through two key components: 

  • Custom Joule Skills: Joule Studio enables the creation of tailored, business-specific Joule skills with flexibly defined logic and third-party integrations, ensuring adaptability and maximizing value. For example, retrieving weather conditions from a third-party API or vendor risks from risk management software.  
  • Custom Joule Agents: Joule Studio supports the development of custom AI Agents, leveraging data from SAP and non-SAP sources to plan and execute complex business scenarios, and enhance decision-making processes. For example, a logistic agent that optimizes shipment delivery routes based on real time data such as weather conditions, carrier availability, and other aspects.  

 

Conceptual: 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Skills and AI agents? 

A: It is important to note the technical differences between custom Joule agents and skills. Below table summarizes it - 

 

 

Joule skills 

AI agents 

Aspects 

Are part of an advanced AI model, and can act on specific operation, by leveraging the context of the conversation 

Are autonomous, multi-tool systems that solve complex problems by selecting and executing appropriate tools dynamically 

Purpose 

Single, predefined and repetitive, atomic operations 

Multi-step, adaptive problem solving 

Complexity 

Simple operations with known inputs/outputs 

Complex, dynamic workflows 

Flexibility 

Limited to predefined actions 

Highly flexible and goal-oriented 

Integration 

Specific APIs via SAP Build actions 

Multi-tool orchestration 

Resource consumption 

Minimal resource consumption 

More resource-intense due to its use of large language models 

 

Q: Is there a list of Joule Skills available and can standard skills be customized? 

A: Standard Joule Skills can be explored in the discovery center, while custom Joule skills will be managed from the Lobby of your SAP Build tenant. In the first release, standard skills will not be customizable. 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Skills and SBPA automations?  

A: Joule Skills act as the essential wrapper for automation built within SAP Build. They expose these processes to the Joule and custom agents in a secure and structured way. If you want Joule to trigger an automation — whether it’s a workflow, a bot, or a system task — you can wrap that logic in a Joule Skill. This allows the Joule and agents to understand what it can do, when it can do it, and how to safely execute it on behalf of the user. 

Q: How do I orchestrate different skills and agents?  

A: These are triggered and orchestrated via Joule based on user intent. So, Joule might call a custom skill to report compliance of vendors or an agent for setting up interviews with a candidate based on user intent and context of conversation. 

Q: What are use cases of Joule skills and AI agents? 

A: Common use cases of Joule Skills include navigation, workflow execution, and decision assistance. Skills can help users navigate specific information or documentation; collect inputs and execute structured workflows; and enhance decision-making by providing predefined insights. 

For agents, common use cases can involve both complex tasks and enterprise-wide executions. Agents handle complex, multistep workflows that require reasoning, adaptability, and contextual awareness. Unlike deterministic automation tools, agents can dynamically adjust processes based on changing business conditions and evolving data inputs. AI agents also bridge disparate systems and business domains—facilitating automations across an enterprise, breaking operational silos, and connecting fragmented IT landscapes. 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Studio and SAP Joule for Developers? 

A: Here, we should draw a clear distinction: Joule for Developers is a collection of AI powered features designed to assist developers in their day-to-day tasks, making activities such as writing code, creating processes, and performing technical operations easier and more efficient with the help of Joule's conversational AI capabilities. 

On the other hand, Joule Studio is evolving into a distinct product within the SAP Build family, focused specifically on building conversational experiences through an agentic approach. Joule Studio is where developers accelerate innovation by creating intelligent, conversational agents that make everyday tasks easier for business users. These agents will augment the workflows and processes that run your business and enhance organizational efficiency.  

In summary, while Joule for Developers optimizes the developer experience, Joule Studio will drive a broader transformation of how work gets done, accelerate innovation and improve usability for both technical teams and business users. 

 

Deployment & Data integration:  

Q: In which regions is Joule Studio available and what version of SAP S/4HANA does it work with (public or private)? 

A: Joule Studio is globally available across US, Europe, and Australia. Please refer to link. There is no dependency on SAP S/4HANA licenses for using Joule Studio, since it is integrated within the SAP Build environment on SAP BTP. So, it works with both public and private cloud versions.   

Q: Do we need to provision the SAP Build in the same tenant as we have Joule to build Joule Skills and agents? 

A: This documentation provides the exact details for setup of Joule Studio via a booster to connect SAP Build and Joule tenants. 

Q: Is it possible to integrate Joule Studio with on premise SAP S/4HANA and is there a minimum version for SAP S/4 HANA required for that integration? 

A: Custom Joule skills and agents can call APIs and BAPIs (via Actions) and Process Automation (built in SAP Build) to interact with on premise SAP S/4HANA system. However, please note that Joule skills and agents are only triggered via Joule, which is not integrated in on premises systems, meaning you will need to get any cloud solution with Joule, for example SAP Start or Build Work Zone. 

There is no dependency on SAP S/4HANA licenses for using Joule Studio, since it is integrated within the SAP Build environment on SAP BTP. 

Q: Can Joule Agent be exposed for on premise deployment after building it on cloud?  

A: Custom Joule agents can call APIs and Process Automations to interact with on premise SAP S/4HANA system. However, please note that Joule skills and agents are only triggered via a Joule, which is not integrated in on premises systems. 

 Q: Is it possible to use data products from SAP Datasphere? 

A: Yes, if you can retrieve this data via API. 

 

Security, Compliance, and Privacy:  

Q: How is personal data protected in prompts sent to agents and LLMs? 

A: Data privacy controls, such as data masking and data filtering, are enforced through the orchestration module of AI core. 

Q: What security roles are needed for the agents to function? 

A: Joule follows the principle of propagation, and both Joule Skills and conversational AI Agents will continue to follow this principle. That means any agent or skill will act within the same security bounds as the user who is chatting with Joule has, inheriting their access and permissions as well. 

 

Availability and Getting Started: 

Q: Is Joule Studio available now? What features are currently available, and what is coming soon? 

A: As of today, developers can access Joule Studio directly from SAP Build lobby and create Joule Skills within Joule Studio. 

Custom AI Agents - General Availability is targeted for the second half of 2025. 

Q: How to get started with Joule Studio? 

A: Joule Studio is now generally available, allowing you to extend and tailor Joule with custom Joule skills. To use Joule Studio, you’ll need Joule Base (or higher) and an SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311). With these, you can build, test, and deploy custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio at no additional cost—aside from the standard execution and runtime charges for the automations, apps, and processes that Joule orchestrates. 

Q: Is SAP Business Data Cloud a prerequisite? 

A: No, SAP Business Data Cloud is not a prerequisite.  

Q: Are there any learning and training resources available to upskill on Joule Studio?  

A: Yes, we have published a learning journey and a tutorial and will release a mission as well for Joule Studio. Please look out for a resource blog in the coming days compiling all resources.   

Q: Are there guided experiences to try Joule Studio?  

A: Yes – we are working on a basic trial experience for Joule Studio which will be published in the coming weeks. There are product tour and interactive value journeys available as guided experiences.  

Q: Is Joule Studio part of the SAP BTP free trial?  

A: No, Joule Studio will not be available on the SAP BTP free trial. We are working on a basic trial and other guided experiences as indicated above.  

Q: How can partners get access to Joule Studio now – is there a test environment or special program? 

A: We plan to have a Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license ready by the end of July, with dependency on SAP Build Everything and Joule Base. Please look out for future updates. 

Q: Can partners build Joule skills & agents and publish them to a store? 

A: Not in the first release - where partners will need to develop these capabilities on the customers' tenants with the necessary configurations. For future updates, we are exploring a store for partner agents and skills. 

Q: If I already have a Build license, can I start using Joule Studio? 

A: You will need an SAP Build developer license to access Joule Studio. If you have any of the older SAP Build licenses, you will not be able to access Joule Studio seamlessly. 

Seamless migration from existing SAP Build services to this SKU is not supported for now.  As a result, some manual configuration will be required at the subaccount level. 

Subscribe to SAP Build using the build_default service plan on another subaccount and ensure that this SAP BTP subaccount includes a subscription to SAP Build Process Automation (set up documentation and mission for reference). 

Manual export and import between subaccounts are required to reuse existing SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) projects, automations, and processes. This limitation applies only to content created prior to the transition. Any new content developed within the new environment will not be affected. 

 

Final remarks: 

I hope this blog answered your questions and helped you feel more confident about getting started with Joule Studio. We’re incredibly excited about what this launch means for our customers and partners and can’t wait to see how they use it to solve unique scenarios. As always, we’re here to support you — don’t hesitate to reach out for questions, feedback, or ideas.

entry.title: Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation
entry.content:
Access Joule Studio from the SAP Build Lobby.

For modern enterprises, we know that harnessing the full potential of business data is essential to making smarter decisions and accelerating innovation. To truly deliver impact, AI agents must go beyond traditional automation – they need to plan and adapt execution based on real-time data and human input. To get the most accurate and relevant results, they need a deep understanding of your unique business data and processes.

That’s why we’re excited to announce the general availability of Joule Studio in SAP Build. With Joule Studio, developers can now start to tailor and extend SAP’s agentic AI to businesses, accelerate workflow automation, and unlock even greater value.

Joule Studio is the latest SAP Build capability where you can extend Joule’s out-of-the-box capabilities with company-specific skills and intelligent agents.

In case you missed it, see the announcement and overview of Joule Studio to understand the unique value it brings deep grounding in business processes & data, an open and extensible framework, and built-in Security & Compliance.

In this post, I’ll share more about what’s available today: custom Joule skills creation in Joule Studio, along with key capabilities, typical use case patterns, and resources for getting started. I’ll also share a sneak peek at what lies ahead with custom AI agents in Joule Studio and how they’ll continue to evolve to support even more complex, cross-system business scenarios.

What are Joule skills?

With today's general availability release, it’s now possible to start expanding Joule’s capabilities using Joule Skills, built with skill builder in Joule Studio, to handle repetitive, rule-based tasks.

Joule skills are modular components within Joule. They leverage the contents of a conversation to complete a specific task.

Here’s a closer look at the key attributes of Joule Skills:

  • Deterministic execution: Joule Skills perform single, predefined operations. These operations can contain multiple steps, such as automations or messages. Each operation contains fixed inputs and outputs, ensuring consistent and efficient results.
  • Natural language understanding: Joule interprets different ways a user might request an operation, ensuring the correct skill is triggered, regardless of phrasing.
  • Context awareness: Joule analyzes user roles, conversation history, and business context to trigger skills only when relevant, avoiding unnecessary executions.
  • Multiple skills working together: Joule Skills are published within a single productive Joule instance, seamlessly combining SAP-provided and custom skills for a unified automation experience.

Joule skills are modular and self-contained, meaning that organizations can start leveraging them to automate everyday tasks without having to add extra layers of complexity. With Joule Studio’s open and extensible framework, skills can be integrated with SAP apps, as well as third-party APIs through SAP Build actions, so they can carry out tasks across systems automatically without needing extra steps or human input.

Explore custom skills further in the Joule Studio product tour.

Typical Use Case Patterns

Joule skills are ideal for handling common, low-complexity requests, freeing your team’s time up from routine tasks. Let’s take a look at some of the common use cases for creating custom Joule skills:

  • Navigation: Allow users to navigate seamlessly across company applications to find specific information, such as IT help resources and HR policies.
  • Data access: Enable users to retrieve, monitor, and track data such as shipping info or optimized delivery routes with real-time traffic updates.
  • System transactions: Structured workflows and system transactions — like IT ticket creation or order management — can be automated and executed via Joule.
  • Workflow execution: Enable Joule to initiate workflow and collect user input for requirements, such as hiring approval processes, facility maintenance requests, or supplier contract renewals.
  • Decision assistance: Enhance decision-making by providing pre-defined insights, such as credit risk evaluation, sales performance forecasting and warehouse demand predictions.

Of course, these only begin to cover the breadth of possibilities that Joule skills offer, as they’re deeply grounded in business data and processes. As part of SAP Build, Joule Studio has native access to all your connectors, automations, apps, and actions — enabling you to reuse assets, leverage shared APIs, and operate within a single governance framework. This tight integration eliminates duplication, accelerates delivery, and ensures consistency across your SAP Build environment. With Joule Studio’s intelligent understanding of existing automations and applications, the skills developers build are not only tailored to unique business needs but also drive real-world outcomes. 

For a deeper understanding of how Joule Studio can integrate and extend SAP and non-SAP solutions, refer to the SAP Reference Architecture within the Architecture Center: https://url.sap/xw5uq7

Several of our SAP Partners have already started to transform their everyday operations with Joule Studio and custom skills. To learn more about their use cases and experiences, check out their blog posts:

  • How sovanta uses Joule Studio to take ticketing systems to the next level
  • How Pricefx is transforming pricing software with Joule Studio in SAP Build
  • How LeverX enhances CAD Data Search for Manufacturing with Joule Studio in SAP Build

Get started creating custom Joule Skills

As we move closer to a more unified experience across SAP Build, the skill-building process is designed to feel intuitive and familiar. Joule Studio makes it easy to dive in and get started, with a setup that feels instantly familiar to anyone who's used SAP Build.

The typical design process includes:

  1. Creating a project in SAP Build: Directly from the SAP Build Lobby, initiate the skill development environment within Joule Studio.
  2. Defining metadata: Add the skill name and description to ensure discoverability, semantic clarity and intent-based Joule orchestration.
  3. Configuring inputs and outputs: Determine what Joule will request from the end user (inputs) and what it will return (outputs), enabling structured communication.
  4. Building the logic flow: Embed existing automation elements such as actions, decisions, and sub-processes with a familiar drag-and-drop simplicity.
  5. Test in the Test Environment: Test how newly created Joule Skill works within the Joule conversation. Ensure that it functions as expected and does not conflict with any other existing Joule Skills.
  6. Release and Deploy to Production: Make project available to end users by deploying it to the specified production environment.

Following SAP Build’s approach, Joule Studio enables both developers and business process experts to start creating. So, whether you’re an enterprise architect looking to extend Joule for your organization’s AI solutions, or a line of business expert hoping to simplify routine requests – Joule Studio now lets you create custom skills with drag-and-drop ease and maximum adaptability.

Completed custom Joule Skill

For a step-by-step guide on creating custom skills, check out the Interactive Value Journey: Designing custom Joule skills in Joule Studio

What’s Next: Pushing the boundaries with custom AI Agents

This is only the beginning for Joule Studio, as we’ll continue to evolve the capabilities further by introducing the agent builder in Joule Studio later this year. With custom AI agents, enterprises can unlock even more complex scenarios, bridging across multiple systems, steps, and tasks.

AI agents used for procurement scenariosHere’s a few examples of what would be possible with custom AI agents:

  • Procurement decision-making: Analyze supplier performance and market trends, helping procurement teams make informed decisions, negotiate better contracts, and ensure supply chain reliability.
  • Talent acquisition: Streamline the recruitment process by reviewing candidates based on resumes, scheduling interviews, and assisting in onboarding (e.g. gathering docs), ensuring faster and efficient hiring.
  • Logistics planning: Optimize delivery routes based on real-time traffic data, weather conditions, and carrier availability, enhancing efficiency and reducing transportation costs.

To understand more about fundamental differences between a Joule skill and agent, read this blog.

Designing a custom AI Agent in Joule Studio. With the general availability of Joule Studio, this marks a meaningful step forward in how work gets done—moving from traditional, linear automation to intelligent, adaptive systems that can handle real-world complexity. As organizations begin to explore their potential, Joule Studio will help teams work smarter, respond faster, and unlock new levels of efficiency across the enterprise.

entry.title: How to Get Started with Joule Studio
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Miguel Angel Meza Martinez and Maria Kondratyeva

How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and AI agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency.

 

Skill Builder in Joule Studio is now Generally Available

At the heart of Joule Studio are custom Joule Skills — purpose-built, reusable logic blocks that can be tailored to your unique business needs. These skills support flexible logic and seamless integration with third-party systems, unlocking automation opportunities across domains. Whether it's retrieving weather data from an external API to inform transport planning, or assessing vendor risks via your risk management platform, Custom Joule Skills let you adapt quickly and deliver real business value.

As Joule Studio reaches General Availability, many early adopters and interested teams are asking the same essential question:

“What are the commercial and technical implications of working with Joule Studio?”

Whether you're a business decision-maker evaluating impact, a developer preparing your technical landscape, or a partner planning ahead for trial licenses — this post outlines what you need to know to get started smoothly and cost-effectively.

Pre-Requisites

Before you dive into building with Joule Studio, make sure your environment includes:

SAP Build

    • Leverage Cloud Integration Automation service scenario for SAP Build to install SAP Build Process Automation service.
    • The SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311) is required to build, test, and deploy your custom Joule Skills.

Joule

    • You will need to have Joule (base or higher).

Commercial Details

There is no additional cost for orchestration and invocation of custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio. This means you do not need AI Units to run custom Joule Skills in your production environments.

That said, it’s important to note that while the orchestration and invocation of a custom skill is free , the underlying components used by your custom Joule Skills will still follow their standard commercial models. For example, if your custom Joule Skill kicks off a business process automation, the usage of SAP Build Process Automation (BTPEA) will still be billed according to the BTPEA pricing structure.

Partner Access – TDD License

For our partners, we recognize how important it is to test, demonstrate, and develop with Joule Studio. That’s why we’re preparing a TDD (Test, Demo, Development) license, which is expected to be ready in the upcoming months. This license will be built on top of SAP Build and Joule. We’ll be sharing updates and specific guidance as we get closer to a release date.

Technical Setup

To ensure proper functionality of Joule Studio within an SAP BTP environment, a defined technical setup process is required. This process establishes secure identity trust, enables core service dependencies, and configures cross-component communication essential for custom Joule Skills orchestration and runtime execution.

At the core of the setup is the need to establish trust between your SAP BTP subaccount and your Identity Authentication tenant.  This trust configuration is mandatory to enable user authentication and token-based authorization flows between Joule Studio and other SAP services.

Concurrently, it is necessary to map user attributes within the SAP Cloud Identity Directory. These attribute mappings (e.g., email, user ID, first name, last name, groups, etc.) are used to support user context resolution and enforce authorization policies during skill execution.

Following trust and attribute configuration, the Joule Booster must be executed. This booster is a guided setup workflow available in SAP BTP and is responsible for:

  • Automatically provisioning required service instances and entitlements
  • Binding SAP Build (build_default service plan) to a productive Joule instance
  • Activating SAP Cloud Identity Services dependencies
  • Validating identity configuration and connectivity across services

The full technical configuration process is documented in the official Joule Studio Set-Up Guide, available in the SAP Help Portal. It is strongly recommended that system administrators follow the documentation precisely, as manual misconfiguration can result in authentication failures, missing service bindings, or broken orchestration flows.

Migration Considerations for Existing SAP Build Customers

Currently, there is no automated or seamless migration path for customers who have previously subscribed to standalone SAP Build services under older SKUs or who have developed content in subaccounts that are not aligned with the new license model required by Joule Studio.

This means that some manual configuration is required at the BTP subaccount level if you wish to transition existing SBPA projects into a new Joule-enabled environment.

Manual Configuration Steps:

  • You will need to create a new SAP BTP subaccount and subscribe to SAP Build using the build_default service plan associated with the new SKU.
  • Within this subaccount, make sure you also subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation, as it is a foundational runtime component for custom Joule Skills that trigger workflows or automations.

Once the new subaccount is configured, you can manually migrate existing SBPA content (such as processes, and automations) using export and import functionality provided by SAP Build tools. It’s important to note that this process is not automatic and may require some post-import validation to ensure dependencies (e.g., destinations, service bindings, user roles) are correctly mapped in the new environment.

This limitation applies only to content developed prior to the transition. Once you are operating within the Joule-enabled subaccount, all newly created content will be natively compatible with Joule Studio and will not require further migration effort.

This is a one-time effort but depending on the complexity of your current SBPA landscape, it may require significant administrative coordination — especially if your original environment includes cross-system integrations, custom scripting logic, or a large number of interdependent workflows.

💡Tip: Before initiating a full migration, consider whether all existing content truly needs to be moved. In many cases, only selected automations and apps need to be reused or triggered from the new environment, while other can continue to run temporarily in the original tenant. This can reduce complexity and allow for a phased migration strategy, where only the most critical elements are prioritized for transition, while others are gradually retired, redesigned, or rebuilt in Joule Studio as needed.

Looking Ahead: What’s Next

Joule Studio is launching with a clear, accessible model: no AI Unit consumption and no additional orchestration cost for custom Joule Skills built with current features. This gives teams a solid foundation to explore, prototype, and scale — without friction.

But this is only the start.

Looking ahead, new SAP Build license will introduce a pay-as-you-go (PAYG) model, providing greater flexibility for customers to adopt Joule Studio capabilities incrementally — without needing a full upfront subscription. This is especially valuable for teams piloting new use cases or scaling adoption gradually.

In addition, a Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license is planned to support SAP partners with dedicated, hands-on environments for prototyping and showcasing Joule-enabled experiences.

As the Joule Studio evolves — with features like AI Agents on the horizon — the commercial model may adapt to reflect expanded functionality. Any changes will be communicated clearly and ahead of time.
