Authors: @Trinidad & @jacobahtan 

As businesses adopt AI at an accelerated pace, the need for AI tools that deeply understand enterprise processes becomes critical. SAP Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, is designed to address this need—offering intelligent, contextual, and secure assistance across the SAP ecosystem.

But what if the out-of-the-box AI capabilities don’t fully match your business needs? Enter SAP Joule Studio, a powerful low-code tool that enables you to build your own Joule Skills, tailor-made for your organization’s workflows.

This blog explores how Joule Studio empowers companies to create custom AI skills, automate repetitive tasks, and seamlessly integrate AI into daily operations.

This is a summary of the business use case I presented together with my colleague @Trinidad in this webinar: Amplify Joule's power for your enterprise needs. Please, note the mentioned session is part of a series of webinars under the topic of “Talk to Your Business with Generative AI”. Check the full calendar here to watch the recordings of past sessions and register for the upcoming one.

 

💡 What is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is an AI copilot designed to provide intelligent, contextual assistance within the SAP ecosystem. Unlike generic AI chatbots, Joule understands SAP business processes, user context, and role-based permissions, allowing it to deliver meaningful, secure, and actionable responses.

🌐 Unified Across the SAP Ecosystem

  • Joule acts as a single AI instance connected to SAP Cloud solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, and SAP Field Service Management (FSM).
  • Users can interact with Joule via an embedded web client, mobile interface (e.g., SAP Mobile Start), or third-party tools like Microsoft Teams.
  • Regardless of the entry point, Joule maintains user context, security, and session continuity.

🤖 Joule's Capabilities: How Does It Work?

When a user interacts with Joule, here’s what happens under the hood

  1. User Input: A natural language query is entered e.g., “Show me open purchase orders for customer ABC.”

  2. Intent Recognition: Joule checks if the query matches:
    • An out-of-the-box skill (prebuilt by SAP)
    • A custom skill developed by the partner/customer
    • Or if it requires a knowledge-based response (e.g., documents or help articles)

  3. Knowledge Filtering: Joule pulls information from:
    • SAP documentation
    • The customer’s own document repositories (document grounding)
    • Application-specific data (e.g., SAP S/4HANA)

  4. Context Gathering:
    • Who is the user?
    • What are their roles, permissions, and session context?
    • What application are they working in?

  5. Query Orchestration:
    • Joule composes an enriched, context-aware query.
    • This is passed to a Large Language Model (LLM) like GPT or Gemini for dialogue generation.

  6. Skill Execution:
    • If the response requires action (e.g., “Create a service ticket”), Joule invokes the appropriate skill or API.

  7. Response Delivery:
    • The answer or action is returned to the user, formatted appropriately (e.g., text, links, buttons).

⚙️ Joule Skills vs. AI Agents: Understanding the Difference

🔧 Joule Skills: Deterministic Automation

Purpose: Automate structured, repetitive tasks with predefined logic.
How it works: When a query matches a defined intent, the corresponding skill executes a fixed workflow.
Example Use Cases:

  • Checking contract validity
  • Retrieving customer orders
  • Creating service tickets

Characteristics:

  • Rule-based
  • Fast and reliable
  • Requires clear input/output definitions

🧠  AI Agents: Dynamic, Reasoning-Powered Automation (Coming Soon)

Purpose: Handle complex tasks with ambiguous goals, requiring reasoning and decision-making.
How it works:

  • Breaks tasks into subtasks autonomously
  • Chooses which APIs, skills, or tools to use
  • Adjusts the execution path based on real-time context

Example Use Cases:

  • Supply chain disruption management (e.g., predicting and mitigating shipment delays)
  • Cross-system troubleshooting with adaptive workflows

Characteristics:

  • Autonomous planning
  • Uses LLMs for reasoning
  • Dynamic execution paths

🔑 In Simple Terms

Skills: “Tell me what to do, and I’ll do it.”

Agents: “Tell me the goal, and I’ll figure out how to get there.”

 

Joule Studio

... is a new tool within SAP Build that lets partners, developers, and customers create, manage, and deploy Joule Skills—custom AI-driven capabilities that extend the functionality of SAP Joule.

✅ Why Joule Studio Matters

  • Automates routine tasks using natural language.
  • Provides an easy-to-use, low-code/no-code interface.
  • Empowers business users and developers to extend SAP Joule without writing extensive code.
  • Seamlessly integrates with both SAP systems and third-party applications.

🎯 Business Value

  • Accelerates productivity by reducing manual work.
  • Provides consistent, AI-powered user experiences across the SAP landscape.
  • Reduces reliance on developers for routine automation tasks.
  • Allows businesses to adapt SAP Joule to their unique processes.

🔧 What are Joule Skills?

Joule Skills are modular AI capabilities that automate deterministic, rule-based tasks in response to natural language queries from users. These tasks are repeatable, well-structured, and follow predefined workflows.

🔍 Examples of Joule Skills

✅ Check if a customer’s service contract is valid in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
✅ Retrieve a list of recent purchase orders.
✅ Generate a service ticket in SAP Field Service Management (FSM).
✅ Fetch relevant SAP documentation based on a keyword or phrase.

🚀 Key Capabilities of Joule Skills

  1. Automate processes based on natural language prompts.
  2. Fetch data, perform transactions, or trigger workflows.
  3. Integrate with APIs, SAP backend systems, or third-party apps.
  4. Provide formatted outputs like lists, summaries, or direct links to SAP systems.

 

🏗️  Building Skills in Joule Studio: How Does it Work?

1. Visual Skill Builder

  • Joule Studio uses a drag-and-drop interface to design skills.
  • Define inputs, outputs, and processing steps without complex coding.

2. API and Action Integration

  • Create actions that connect to SAP APIs (e.g., S/4HANA, FSM) or third-party systems.
  • Support for importing OpenAPI specifications simplifies the process.
  • Create custom REST calls easily within the skill.

3. Workflow Orchestration

  • Chain multiple actions together.
  • Add conditions, branching logic, or loops.
  • Incorporate SAP Build Process Automation workflows or decisions.

4. Response Customization

  • Define how outputs are presented:
    • Text summaries
    • Lists with links (e.g., to a contract or service call)
    • Status updates
  • Full control over the user interaction format.

5. Secure Deployment via Environments

  • Deploy skills into specific environments (Dev, QA, Production).
  • Manage role-based access for both developers and users.
  • Enforce security with principal propagation and identity checks.

6. Monitoring & Lifecycle Management

  • Visualize skill execution paths.
  • Debug failed steps directly within Joule Studio.
  • Manage skill versions and rollback if needed.

🧠 How Joule Skills Enhance SAP Joule

  1. Deep Contextual Awareness: Skills leverage user identity, permissions, and current session context, ensuring responses are both relevant and secure.
  2. Unified Access: Users can invoke skills from within any SAP application where Joule is embedded, without switching apps or screens.
  3. Extensibility: You can extend SAP’s out-of-the-box skills by layering in your company-specific logic, processes, or data sources.

 

🏗️ Example Use Case: Smart Advisory Companion

🏢 Business Problem

A consultant named John needs to handle customer requests like “How do I implement multi-tenancy in SAP BTP?”. Today, John manually checks contract validity, looks for similar projects, gathers documents, creates service calls, and emails customers—a time-consuming process.

💡 Solution with Joule Studio

Joule Studio powers five key Joule Skills that automate this workflow:

1. Check Service Contract Validity:

Queries S/4HANA Cloud to check if the customer’s service contract is active. If expired, sends John a link to renew it.

2. Find Similar Projects:

Connects to a backend that uses SAP HANA Cloud’s Vector Engine for semantic search, retrieving the most relevant past projects.

3. Retrieve Related Documents:

Searches for relevant SAP documentation or internal files based on the customer’s request.

4. Create a Service Call:

Automatically logs a service ticket in SAP FSM, using data gathered from previous steps.

5. Send Summary Email:

Automatically composes and sends a summary email to the customer, containing all gathered information, ticket IDs, document links, and next steps.

🎯Result

John spends less time navigating systems and more time delivering value to customers.

🏛️ Solution Architecture for the Use Case

Component

Functionality

SAP Joule Studio

Skill authoring, deployment, lifecycle management

SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Service contract validation

SAP FSM

Service call creation

Smart Advisory Backend

Semantic search using vector databases

SAP HANA Cloud

Data storage, vector search, knowledge graph

SAP Build Process Automation

Email workflows, task management

Generative AI Hub

LLMs for document analysis or summarization

 

🏗️ Setting Up the Foundation: Joule Studio Environment

✔️Environment Creation

  • A Joule Studio Environment acts as a sandbox where you can develop, test, and deploy your Joule Skills.
  • It controls the deployment versions and provides isolation between development, QA, and production.

✔️Connecting Systems via Destinations

  • The team set up Destinations in SAP BTP for:
  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud (contract validation)
  2. SAP FSM (service ticket creation)
  3. A Custom Smart Advisory Backend (handles semantic search and knowledge graphs)
  • Destinations allow Joule Skills to securely communicate with SAP APIs and third-party services.

✔️Action Projects: How to “bridge” your Destinations with Joule Skills

1. Import from API Specification:

  • Upload your OpenAPI-formatted API specification file.
  • Select specific endpoints you need – no need for everything.
  • Test endpoints immediately to define accurate outputs.
  • System auto-generates output fields, which you can then refine.

2. Define Custom Actions:

  • Manually configure endpoints and parameters.
  • Ideal for custom integrations (e.g., S/4HANA Service Contracts).
  • Test to automatically generate and then modify output fields.

Creating Your Joule Skill Project

Once your actions are defined:

  • In the lobby, select "Joule Skill."
  • Give it a clear name and, crucially, a very specific description. This clarity is vital for effective utilization.

 

🛠️ Deep Dive of Joule Skills Development for our Use Case

🔍 Skill 1: Retrieve Similar Projects

Purpose: Search for top 5 similar projects based on a natural language query.

Process:

  1. Created an Action Project by importing an OpenAPI specification from the backend.
  2. Defined the API endpoint to query the vector database that holds historical project embeddings.
  3. Defined input (search term) and output (project list) parameters.
  4. Created a Joule Skill named Retrieve Similar Projects.
  5. The skill was configured to automatically generate a user-friendly list with project titles and links.

Result: John can type “Find me similar projects about multi-tenancy” and Joule returns a clickable list of past projects.

📄 Skill 2: Retrieve SAP Documents

Purpose: Retrieve SAP-related documents relevant to the query.

Process:

  1. Added an action that queries a document repository API (e.g., SAP Help, SharePoint).
  2. Configured a Send Message step to customize how the documents are displayed (title, snippet, document type, and clickable links).
  3. Disabled automatic response formatting to fully control how Joule presents the information.

Result: John asks “Show me documents about ABAP Cloud”, and Joule returns a curated list of relevant documentation with descriptions and links.

📝 Skill 3: Check Service Contract Validity

Purpose: Verify whether a customer’s service contract in S/4HANA Cloud is active or expired.

Process:

  1. Created an action to call the Get Service Contract API from S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Defined input as the Service Contract ID.
  3. Built a Condition Branch to check whether the contract status contains the string “Active”.
  4. Configured two possible outcomes:
    - If active: returns a confirmation message.
    - If expired: displays a message with a button linking to the contract for renewal.

Result: John can input “Check contract SC-0001” and Joule tells him whether it’s valid or expired, with quick navigation links.

🔧 Skill 4: Create Service Call in FSM

Purpose: Open a service call in SAP FSM based on the current advisory conversation.

Process:

  1. Confirmed the service contract validity using the skill from the previous step.
  2. If valid, created an action to call FSM’s Create Service Call API.
  3. Populated the service call details using information gathered (e.g., subject from John’s advisory request).
  4. Designed the output message to include:
    - The Service Call ID.
    - A link to the FSM interface for further details.
    - Status and remarks.

Result: With a simple command like “Open a service call for this customer”, Joule creates the FSM ticket instantly.

📧 Skill 5: Send Summary Email

Purpose: Summarize the conversation and send an email to the customer or internal stakeholders.

Process:

  1. Used SAP Build Process Automation to handle email sending.
  2. Created a Process Project for email with parameters like:
    - To and CC email addresses.
    - Email body parts.
    - Subject line.
  3. Published this process into the Joule Studio library.
  4. Built a Joule Skill to trigger the process as part of the workflow.

Result: John types “Send a summary email”, and Joule automatically drafts and sends a detailed email containing:
- Contract status.
- List of related projects.
- Documents.
- Service call details.

Use Case end-to-end Demonstration

🧠 Key Features Showcased in the Demo

  1. Dynamic Input Handling: Skills captured user prompts dynamically (e.g., keywords, contract IDs).
  2. API Testing Built-In: While creating actions, the API responses were tested in real-time to auto-generate output fields.
  3. Decision Branching: Contract validation skill used IF/THEN logic directly in the visual flow.
  4. Data Formatting: Output lists, clickable links, and summaries were customized for each skill.
  5. Environment Management: Demonstrated deploying skills into the testing environment with destination mappings.
  6. Error Handling: Skills were designed with fallback messages in case of API failures or missing data.

 

🔭 What’s Next for Joule Studio?

🚩 July 2025:

✅ GA (General Availability) of Joule Studio for Custom Skills.

🚀 Later in 2025:

✅ AI Agents Development:

  • Leverages the same framework.
  • Adds autonomous planning, multi-step reasoning, and complex problem solving.
  • The presenters concluded by giving a teaser of the next evolution—AI Agents—which will further extend Joule’s capabilities by introducing autonomous, multi-step reasoning and decision-making, enabling even more complex workflows beyond deterministic skills.

 

📚 Learning Resources and Next Steps:

  • Explore the SAP Joule Product Page (placeholder link)
  • Join the SAP AI Community to connect with experts
  • Review the SAP Roadmap for upcoming features
  • Watch our Webinar Recording to revisit the detailed demo and implementation guide

 

✨ Conclusion: Your Enterprise, Smarter with Joule Studio

Joule Studio transforms how businesses interact with SAP systems. By enabling you to build custom Joule Skills, you automate routine tasks, reduce operational complexity, and unlock the power of natural language-driven workflows.

This isn’t just automation—it’s intelligent, context-aware assistance designed for enterprise scale, security, and flexibility.

As the evolution continues with AI Agents, Joule Studio will be the central hub where your AI-driven enterprise solutions come to life.

entry.title: Adding OAuth 2.0 to existing Go application and deploying it on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Good day !

First of all, there is a great blog post about building Restfull API using Go for PostgreSQL HyperScale Option on BTP, that needs to be read as reference.

This Article will assume, that you already have your own Go application and need to add OAuth 2.0 authorization to it.

In my example i will use application "rest-logs" for the context.

Small note: i will hide long code samples and screenshots under the spoiler tags, to avoid possible complications with poor screenshots quality in case of change of image size.

 

Step 1
Create instance of service "Authorization and Trust Management Service" (xsuaa).
It can be done directly at BTP or via console. In both cases, we would need Application Security Descriptor with specific syntax. We need:

  • xsappname - name of the application
  • tenant-mode - to define the way the tenant's OAuth clients get their client secrets
  • scopes - array of properties to divide authorization
  • role-templates - array with roles that would be generated at xsuaa instance creation
  • role-collections - array with list of role collections where we would assign users later

Entire "xs-security.json" is under the spoiler:

Spoiler
{
  "xsappname": "xsuaa-rest-logs-app",
  "tenant-mode": "dedicated",
  "scopes": [{
    "name": "$XSAPPNAME.view",
    "description": "Scope required for viewing Rest Logs."
  },{
    "name": "$XSAPPNAME.write",
    "description": "Scope required for writing Rest Logs."
  }
  ],
  "role-templates": [{
    "name": "RestLogsView",
    "description": "Allows to view Rest Logs.",
    "scope-references": ["$XSAPPNAME.view"]
  },{
    "name": "RestLogsWrite",
    "description": "Allows to write Rest Logs.",
    "scope-references": ["$XSAPPNAME.write"]
  }
  ],
  "role-collections": [{
    "name": "RestLogsUserRoles",
    "role-template-references": [ "$XSAPPNAME.RestLogsView" ]
  },{
    "name": "RestLogsConsultantRoles",
    "role-template-references": [ "$XSAPPNAME.RestLogsWrite" ]
  }
  ]
}

Via BTP:
BTP -> subaccount -> Create:

Spoiler

on next tab we add our xs-security.json content:

Spoiler

And then create the instance.

In generated instance, we create a binding to our application:

Spoiler

Via console:
follow the commands:

cf create-service xsuaa application xsuaa-rest-logs -c xs-security.json
cf bind-service rest-logs xsuaa-rest-logs

Result would be:

Spoiler


Step 2
It's time to adjust the application itself.
In ".env" file we add "XSUAA_JWKS_URL" param/variable that we would use later to retrieve the public keys needed to validate JWTs.

DB_HOST=postgres-1*******7.c******s.us-east-1.rds.amazonaws.com
DB_PORT=6**4
DB_USER_NAME=7********e5
DB_PASSWORD=3****************8ac
DB_NAME=p*******RH
XSUAA_JWKS_URL=https://*******trial.authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/token_keys

In "manifest.yml" we update "services" section to specify that "xsuaa-rest-logs" instance is bounded to our application:

applications:
  - name: rest-logs
    memory: 512M
    buildpacks:
      - go_buildpack
    services:
      - postgreSQL
      - xsuaa-rest-logs

 

Step 3
Create new package "authorize" and new Go file "auth.go" inside. There would be an authorization logic. For that we would need to install libraries:

go get github.com/golang-jwt/jwt/v4
go get github.com/MicahParks/keyfunc

In "auth.go" we would:

  • Extract a JWT from the HTTP request
  • Validate the token using public keys from xsuaa
  • Check the allowed scope
  • Allow access only if the token is valid

We need to be aware, that when we generate xsuaa instance, "xsappname" (that was specified in "xs-security.json" earlier) of our application would be changed. Xsuaa instance would add tenant suffix to it and, since we are using "$XSAPPNAME" - scopes also would be changed.
Because of that it's important to retrieve "xsappname":

	xsappname := os.Getenv("XSUAA_XSAPPNAME")
	if xsappname != "" {
		return xsappname + "." + suffix
	}

It can be also retrieved from "VCAP_SERVICES":

	vcap := os.Getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
	if vcap != "" {
***

You can see the structure of "VCAP_SERVICES" by command:

cf env rest-logs

We would need it for dynamic check.

Entire "auth.go" under the spoiler:

Spoiler
package authorize

import (
	"encoding/json"
	"errors"
	"log"
	"net/http"
	"os"
	"strings"
	"sync"
	"time"

	"github.com/MicahParks/keyfunc"
	"github.com/golang-jwt/jwt/v4"
)

var (
	jwks     *keyfunc.JWKS
	jwksOnce sync.Once
	jwksErr  error
)

// AuthScopeByMethod dynamically resolves xsappname and checks for full scope
func AuthScopeByMethod(next http.HandlerFunc) http.HandlerFunc {
	return func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
		tokenStr := extractToken(r)
		if tokenStr == "" {
			http.Error(w, "Missing or malformed Authorization header", http.StatusUnauthorized)
			return
		}

		jwksOnce.Do(func() {
			jwks, jwksErr = loadJWKSFromXSUAA()
		})
		if jwksErr != nil {
			http.Error(w, "Failed to load JWKS: "+jwksErr.Error(), http.StatusInternalServerError)
			return
		}

		token, err := jwt.Parse(tokenStr, jwks.Keyfunc)
		if err != nil || !token.Valid {
			http.Error(w, "Invalid token: "+err.Error(), http.StatusUnauthorized)
			return
		}

		claims, ok := token.Claims.(jwt.MapClaims)
		if !ok {
			http.Error(w, "Invalid token claims", http.StatusUnauthorized)
			return
		}

		requiredScope := ""
		switch r.Method {
		case http.MethodGet:
			requiredScope = getXSAppScope("view")
		case http.MethodPost:
			requiredScope = getXSAppScope("write")
		default:
			http.Error(w, "Method not allowed", http.StatusMethodNotAllowed)
			return
		}

		log.Printf("Required scope: %s", requiredScope)
		log.Printf("Available scopes: %+v", claims["scope"])

		if hasScope(claims, requiredScope) {
			next(w, r)
			return
		}

		// If missing, include them in the error response
		w.WriteHeader(http.StatusForbidden)
		w.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/json")
		json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(map[string]interface{}{
			"error":            "Forbidden: missing required scope",
			"required_scope":   requiredScope,
			"available_scopes": claims["scope"],
		})
	}
}

func hasScope(claims jwt.MapClaims, required string) bool {
	if scopes, ok := claims["scope"].([]interface{}); ok {
		for _, s := range scopes {
			if str, ok := s.(string); ok && str == required {
				return true
			}
		}
	}
	if scopeStr, ok := claims["scope"].(string); ok {
		for _, s := range strings.Split(scopeStr, " ") {
			if s == required {
				return true
			}
		}
	}
	return false
}

func extractToken(r *http.Request) string {
	authHeader := r.Header.Get("Authorization")
	if strings.HasPrefix(authHeader, "Bearer ") {
		return strings.TrimPrefix(authHeader, "Bearer ")
	}
	return ""
}

func loadJWKSFromXSUAA() (*keyfunc.JWKS, error) {
	vcap := os.Getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
	var jwksURI string

	if vcap == "" {
		jwksURI = os.Getenv("XSUAA_JWKS_URL")
		if jwksURI == "" {
			return nil, errors.New("XSUAA_JWKS_URL not set and VCAP_SERVICES is missing")
		}
		log.Println("Resolved JWKS URI (from XSUAA_JWKS_URL):", jwksURI)
	} else {
		var vcapMap map[string]interface{}
		if err := json.Unmarshal([]byte(vcap), &vcapMap); err != nil {
			return nil, err
		}
		services := vcapMap["xsuaa"].([]interface{})
		credentials := services[0].(map[string]interface{})["credentials"].(map[string]interface{})
		urlStr := credentials["url"].(string)
		jwksURI = urlStr + "/token_keys"
		log.Println("Resolved JWKS URI (from VCAP_SERVICES):", jwksURI)
	}

	options := keyfunc.Options{
		RefreshInterval: time.Hour,
		RefreshErrorHandler: func(err error) {
			log.Printf("JWKS refresh error: %v", err)
		},
	}

	return keyfunc.Get(jwksURI, options)
}

func getXSAppScope(suffix string) string {
	// Try environment variable first
	xsappname := os.Getenv("XSUAA_XSAPPNAME")
	if xsappname != "" {
		return xsappname + "." + suffix
	}
	// Try to parse from VCAP_SERVICES
	vcap := os.Getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
	if vcap != "" {
		var vcapMap map[string]interface{}
		if err := json.Unmarshal([]byte(vcap), &vcapMap); err == nil {
			if services, ok := vcapMap["xsuaa"].([]interface{}); ok && len(services) > 0 {
				if service, ok := services[0].(map[string]interface{}); ok {
					if credentials, ok := service["credentials"].(map[string]interface{}); ok {
						if xsappname, ok := credentials["xsappname"].(string); ok {
							return xsappname + "." + suffix
						}
					}
				}
			}
		}
	}

	// If all else fails, return just the suffix
	return suffix
}

Now we need to update "main.go" file:

  • Import package where "auth.go" is 
"rest-logs/authorize"​
  • Update the route to use authorization
	http.HandleFunc("/logs", authorize.AuthScopeByMethod(handlers.UserHandler))  // for POST
	http.HandleFunc("/logs/", authorize.AuthScopeByMethod(handlers.UserHandler)) // for GET

Our implementation of "xsappname" check at previous file "auth.go" allows us not to worry about deployment on different landscapes. We would not need to update routes. Otherwise, we would need to specify hardcoded scope there, like:

http.HandleFunc("/logs/", authorize.AuthScopeByMethod(handlers.UserHandler, "xsuaa-rest-logs-app!t******.view"))


Entire "main.go" under the spoiler:

Spoiler
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"log"
	"net/http"
	"os"
	"rest-logs/authorize"
	"rest-logs/db"
	"rest-logs/handlers"

	"github.com/joho/godotenv"
)

func main() {
	// Load environment variables from .env (if it exists)
	if err := godotenv.Load(); err != nil {
		log.Println(".env file not found or failed to load")
	}

	// Connect to the database
	db.Connect()

	// Endpoint
	http.HandleFunc("/logs", authorize.AuthScopeByMethod(handlers.UserHandler))  // for POST
	http.HandleFunc("/logs/", authorize.AuthScopeByMethod(handlers.UserHandler)) // for GET

	// Default route
	http.HandleFunc("/", func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
		fmt.Fprintln(w, "Welcome to Rest Logs!"+
			"\nUse POST /logs to write, and GET /logs/{params} to read logs. Example: /logs/messageid='XXXXX'")
	})

	// Start server
	port := ":8080"
	if envPort := os.Getenv("PORT"); envPort != "" {
		port = ":" + envPort
	}
	log.Printf("Server is running on http://localhost%s", port)
	if err := http.ListenAndServe(port, nil); err != nil {
		log.Fatal("Server error:", err)
	}
}

And finally push the updated application:

cf push

Note: in case you deployed application before creating the binding, you would need execute restage command, so the application would take the updates:

cf restage rest-logs


Step 4
Create service key and test via Postman.
Service key can be created at BTP as usual or via console:

cf create-service-key xsuaa-rest-logs rest-logs-user

 

Spoiler

We are gonna test it twice:

  • before assigning role collection to our user
  • after assigning role collection

to see the difference in token content.

In Postman we create GET request with OAuth 2.0 authorization.

  • Grant Type: password credentials
  • Client Id: from service key
  • Client Secret: from service key
  • Access Token Url: from service key + /oauth/token
  • Username: your BTP user
  • Password: your BTP password
Spoiler

Take this Access Token

Spoiler

and go to https://jwt.io to the JWT Token Decoder. At right side we would see decoded information and would see the scopes:

***
  "scope": [
    "openid"
  ],
  "client_id": "sb
***

If we use this Token in postman, exception about "missing required scope" appear:

Spoiler


Now let's assign our BTP User to role collections:
BTP Cockpit -> Role Collections and search for our collections

Spoiler

Inside collections you will see already assigned role and we need to add our BTP User.

Spoiler

Do the same for the second collection. 

Now we can generate new Token and again check it at https://jwt.io.
This time we would see our scopes added to it:

***
  "scope": [
    "xsuaa-rest-logs-app!t******.write",
    "openid",
    "xsuaa-rest-logs-app!t******.view"
  ],
  "client_id": "sb
***

As it was mentioned before, since we used "$XSAPPNAME", scopes are changed due to added generated tenant suffix from xsuaa.

Result of this token usage would be http 200 code with requested data:

Spoiler

Spoiler

entry.title: Accessing S/4HANA Cloud Data via SAP Build Code on the SAP BTP Platform
entry.content:
Recently, I had the opportunity to contribute to the development of an agentic use case, where I need to fetch data from an S/4HANA Cloud system using existing OData services. This experience gave me hands-on exposure to working with S/4HANA Cloud and understanding how to integrate its data seamlessly into an external application.

In this blog post, I’ll walk you through the step-by-step process of retrieving data from an S/4HANA Cloud system using OData.

What is SAP Business Technology Platform?

SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) is SAP’s unified platform-as-a-service (PaaS) offering that provides tools, services, and runtimes for building, integrating, and extending SAP and non-SAP applications in the cloud.

What is SAP Cloud Connector?

The SAP Cloud Connector is a key component in the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) landscape. It acts as a secure bridge between your on-premise systems (like SAP S/4HANA on-prem or other internal services) and SAP BTP or cloud-based applications.

What is Destination Service?

The SAP Destination Service is a managed service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) that simplifies and secures how your cloud applications connect to remote systems such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud, on-premise systems, or third-party APIs.

Instead of hardcoding URLs, credentials, and connection details inside your app, you create a destination configuration in BTP and refer to it in your code.

Download and Install SAP Cloud Connector

You can download the Cloud Connector compatible with your machine from the following link: https://tools.hana.ondemand.com/#cloud

                                    Fig 1. Cloud Connector download

For Windows, you can choose between the ZIP archive and the MSI installer. The ZIP archive is suitable for development use cases, while the MSI installer is recommended for productive environments, as it installs the Cloud Connector as a service on the server.

Initial Configuration 

To configure the SCC, open a browser and navigate to:
https://<hostname>:8443

Replace <hostname> with the name of the machine where the connector is installed. The port number should match the one configured during installation, by default, it is 8443.

To find the hostname of your machine, open Command Prompt and enter:
hostname

                 Fig 2. Cloud Connector Login 

Enter the default credentials (case-sensitive) and click Login:

Username: Administrator

Password: manage

Upon your first login, you'll be prompted to change the password. After updating it, select Master as the installation type and click Save.

                                                       Fig 3. Reset password for SCC

The next step is to add your BTP subaccount to the Cloud Connector.

Select "Choose Manually" to enter your subaccount details manually.

On the following screen, provide the required information about your BTP subaccount. This is necessary to establish a secure tunnel between the Cloud Connector (SCC) and your SAP BTP subaccount.

Region: The region where your subaccount was created (see the picture below).

Subaccount: Your subaccount ID (see the picture below).

Login E-Mail: The email address used when creating the BTP account.

Password: The password used when creating the BTP account.

 

                                              Fig 4. Connect BTP Sub Account to SCC

 

                      Fig 5: Cloud Connector – BTP Sub Account Registration

Once successfully added your sub account you will see the screenshot as below:

                                 Fig 6. Successful Sub Account Registration

This shows that you have successfully connected your sub account with the cloud connector.

Now its time to connect your On-Premise system.

Connecting “Cloud to On-Premise” Connection:

Connect your on-premise system to the cloud connector so that it can be access in Business Technology Platform.

Under the sub account ID in your cloud connector click on Cloud to On-Premise in the left menu and then click on ‘+’ sign to add the system.

                                    Fig 7. Add S/4 HANA Cloud System in SCC

In the pop up that open choose ABAP System as the backend type and choose protocol as HTTP.

                                    Fig 8. Add Back End system type

                        Fig 9: Define Protocol for Backend Connection

For the “internal host” use the hostname or the ip address of the ABAP system and its corresponding ICM port number.

                              Fig 10: Configuring System Host Details

The “Virtual Host” is the hostname you'll use within BTP. You can either use the default value, which matches the Internal Host, or choose a different, less identifiable name.

                               Fig 11. Configuring Virtual Host

We'll leave the “Principal Type” set to “None” for now.

                          Fig 12. Configure Principal Propagation

Select to use virtual host for “Host in Request Header”.

                         Fig 13: Selecting Virtual Host Option

Provide the SAP ABAP system name.

                                 Fig 14. Selecting ABAP System 

Check the summary and click on finish.

                                                 Fig 15. Summary

After successfully creating mapping we need to create resource which is the actual service. Click on the ‘+’ sign under the resources section.

                                                          Fig 16: Resource 

To grant the subaccount access to all services, enter /sap in the URL path and choose "Path and All Sub-Paths" under the Access Policy setting. This setup can be adjusted later to restrict access to specific resources, which is strongly advised for production environments.

                                Fig 17: Adding a New Resource

Now check the resource available and ensure that the backend system is reachable as below:

                                     Fig 18. Check for connection status

Once the system is reachable you will see the status as below:

                                    Fig 19: Verifying System Reachability

If you face some issues in reaching backend system maintain the below configurations at

“Run->drivers->Click on ok-> Go to etc folder->edit hosts”

Add the host details at the bottom and click on SAVE as an example below:

 127.54.99.98    test.com

If not able to edit copy paste in different location and then change and paste again.

Now you will be able to see the connected CC in your BTP account as below:

                                     Fig 20. Cloud Connector status in BTP

Create a Destination Service

Now lets create a destination service.

BTP (Business Technology Platform) destinations serve as configuration endpoints that define how to establish secure connections with external systems or services. Commonly used in cloud environments, these destinations facilitate communication between different cloud-based applications by specifying connection parameters like endpoint URLs, authentication methods, and additional settings. You can create and manage BTP destinations through the SAP BTP Cockpit or by using the SAP Cloud SDK. They are applicable in various use cases, including accessing external data sources, calling third-party web services, or delivering notifications to external platforms.

                                   Fig 21: Creating a Destination in SAP BTP

Maintain the below configuration details:

Name: Name of your destination

Type: HTTP / HTTPS

URL: Enter the virtual host name maintained in Cloud Connector

Authentication: Basic Authentication

User: Enter the backend username

Password: Enter the corresponding password

In the additional properties maintain the below pairs:

"WebIDEEnabled": "true"

“HTML5.DynamicDestination” :"true"

"AppgyverEnabled" :"true"

“sap-platform”:”ABAP”

“sap.build.usage”:”true”

“webIDEUsage”:”odata_gen”

“sap-client”:”000”

These parameters are mantatory in certain ways to consume the destination service via SAP Build Code.

                                            Fig 22. BTP Destination Service

Click on “Save” to save the destination and click on Check Destination to check if the connection is successful.

                                             Fig 23. Check Connection

Create a SAP Build Code Project

Now lets create a SAP Build code project. Go to Instances and Subscription and click on SAP Build Code. Hope the SAP Build code is already subscribed to your sub account.

In the SAP Build Code click on Create to create a new project.

                                    Fig 24. Create a SAP Build Code project

Click on Application -> Next -> Full Stack -> Next -> Full stack Node.JS

Enter the name of the project and click on Review to review the details and then click on Create to create the project.

Once the project is created copy paste the below code:

For demonstration purposes, I have used an example involving the retrieval and modification of Purchase Order data.

from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import os
import requests
import json
import base64

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Application Initialization
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
app = Flask(__name__)

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Fetching port details
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
cf_port = os.getenv("PORT")

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Getting OAuth Token
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
def get_oauth_token(destination_credentials):
    oauth_url = destination_credentials['url'] + "/oauth/token"
    client_id = destination_credentials['clientid']
    client_secret = destination_credentials['clientsecret']

    data = {
        'grant_type': 'client_credentials',
        'client_id': client_id,
        'client_secret': client_secret,
    }

    headers = {
        'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'
    }

    response = requests.post(oauth_url, data=data, headers=headers)

    if response.status_code == 200:
        return response.json()['access_token']
    else:
        raise Exception(f"Failed to get OAuth token: {response.status_code} - {response.text}")

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Method to fetch records 
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
def get_records(lv_dest, lv_string):
    # Get VCAP_SERVICES
    vcap_services = json.loads(os.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES"))

    # Get credentials for Destination service
    destination_credentials = vcap_services['destination'][0]['credentials']
    connectivity_credentials = vcap_services['connectivity'][0]['credentials']
    destination_name = lv_dest
    dest_token = get_oauth_token(destination_credentials)

    # Fetch destination config
    dest_url = f"{destination_credentials['uri']}/destination-configuration/v1/destinations/{destination_name}"
    headers = {"Authorization": f"Bearer {dest_token}"}
    dest_response = requests.get(dest_url, headers=headers)
    dest_response.raise_for_status()
    dest_config = dest_response.json()['destinationConfiguration']

    #  Build full URL
    target_url = dest_config['URL'] + lv_string

    # Token for Connectivity Proxy
    conn_token = get_oauth_token(connectivity_credentials)

    # Use Connectivity Proxy (Cloud Connector)
    proxies = {
        "http": f"http://{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_host']}:{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_port']}",
        "https": f"http://{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_host']}:{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_port']}"
    }

    backend_user = dest_config['User']
    backend_password = dest_config['Password']
    auth_string = f"{backend_user}:{backend_password}"
    auth_encoded = base64.b64encode(auth_string.encode()).decode()

    # Headers for proxy request
    headers = {
        "Accept": "application/json",
        "Proxy-Authorization": f"Bearer {conn_token}",
        "Authorization": f"Basic {auth_encoded}"
    }

    if 'CloudConnectorLocationId' in dest_config:
        headers['SAP-Connectivity-SCC-Location_ID'] = dest_config['CloudConnectorLocationId']

    # Make the proxied request
    response = requests.get(target_url, headers=headers, proxies=proxies)
    response.raise_for_status()
    print("Status:", response.status_code)
    print("Headers:", response.headers)
    print("Body:", response.text)
    return response.json()

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Method to update a record
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
def update_record(destination_name, path, payload):
    # Get VCAP_SERVICES
    vcap_services = json.loads(os.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES"))

    # Get credentials for Connectivity and Destination service
    destination_credentials = vcap_services['destination'][0]['credentials']
    connectivity_credentials = vcap_services['connectivity'][0]['credentials']
    dest_token = get_oauth_token(destination_credentials)

    # Destination config
    dest_url = f"{destination_credentials['uri']}/destination-configuration/v1/destinations/{destination_name}"
    headers = {"Authorization": f"Bearer {dest_token}"}
    dest_response = requests.get(dest_url, headers=headers)
    dest_response.raise_for_status()
    dest_config = dest_response.json()['destinationConfiguration']

    #  Build full URL
    target_url = dest_config['URL'] + path

    # Token for Connectivity Proxy
    conn_token = get_oauth_token(connectivity_credentials)

    # Use Connectivity Proxy (Cloud Connector)
    proxies = {
        "http": f"http://{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_host']}:{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_port']}",
        "https": f"http://{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_host']}:{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_port']}"
    }

    backend_user = dest_config['User']
    backend_password = dest_config['Password']
    auth_string = f"{backend_user}:{backend_password}"
    auth_encoded = base64.b64encode(auth_string.encode()).decode()

    # Headers for proxy request
    common_headers = {
        "Proxy-Authorization": f"Bearer {conn_token}",
        "Authorization": f"Basic {auth_encoded}",
        "Accept": "application/json"
    }

    if 'CloudConnectorLocationId' in dest_config:
        common_headers['SAP-Connectivity-SCC-Location_ID'] = dest_config['CloudConnectorLocationId']

    # Fetch CSRF Token and Cookies
    token_headers = common_headers.copy()
    token_headers["x-csrf-token"] = "Fetch"

    session = requests.Session()
    token_response = session.get(target_url, headers=token_headers, proxies=proxies)

    if token_response.status_code != 200:
        return token_response.status_code, token_response.text

    csrf_token = token_response.headers.get("x-csrf-token")
    if not csrf_token:
        return 403, "CSRF token not returned"

    # Send PATCH with token and cookies
    update_headers = common_headers.copy()
    update_headers["x-csrf-token"] = csrf_token
    update_headers["Content-Type"] = "application/json"

    # Use session to preserve cookies
    patch_response = session.patch(target_url, headers=update_headers, json=payload, proxies=proxies)

    return patch_response.status_code, patch_response.text

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Update endpoint (POST or GET for testing)
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
@app.route('/update_data', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def update_data():
    if request.method == 'GET':
        purchase_order = "12345"
        item = "10"
        update_payload = {
            "DocumentCurrency": "EUR",
        }
    else:
        if not request.is_json:
            return jsonify({"error": "Request must be application/json"}), 415

        data = request.get_json()
        purchase_order = data.get("PurchaseOrder")
        item = data.get("PurchaseOrderItem")

        if not purchase_order or not item:
            return jsonify({"error": "Missing PurchaseOrder or PurchaseOrderItem"}), 400

        item = str(item).zfill(5)  # Pad item number to 5 digits

        update_payload = {
            "OrderQuantity": 15,
        }

    path = f"/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_purchaseorder_2/srvd_a2x/sap/purchaseorder/0001/PurchaseOrderItem(PurchaseOrder='{purchase_order}',PurchaseOrderItem='{item}')?sap-client=001&$format=json" #Change the OData URL

    status_code, response_text = update_record('Destination_name', path, update_payload) #Modify Destination name

    return jsonify({
        "status_code": status_code,
        "response": response_text
    })

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Fetch record endpoint
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
@app.route('/fetch_data', methods=['GET'])
def fetch_data():
    lv_request = get_records('Destination_name', '/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_purchaseorder_2/srvd_a2x/sap/purchaseorder/0001/PurchaseOrderItem?sap-client=001&$format=json') #Change Destination name and OData URL
    return jsonify(lv_request)

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Home page
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
@app.route('/', methods=['GET'])
def home():
    lv_return = {
        "result": [
            {
                'message':  'Welcome to the homepage!',
                'Fetch_data' : 'Use /fetch_data',
                'Update_data' : 'Use /update_data'
            }
        ]
    }
    return jsonify(status='200', replies=lv_return)


# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Main method
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
if __name__ == '__main__':
# If the app is running locally
    if cf_port is None:
# Use port 5000
        app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000, debug=True)
    else:
# Else use cloud foundry default port
        app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=int(cf_port), debug=False)

Create a manifest.yml file and paste the below:

---
applications:
- name: data_read  #Replace with your app name
  random-route: true
  path: ./
  memory: 1028M
  buildpacks:
  - python_buildpack
  command: python backend.py  #Python file name
  services:
  - service_name_001
  env:
    PYTHON_VERSION: 3.11.10

In the manifest.yml file above, most sections are self-explanatory and have been annotated with comments. The key part to focus on is the services section. To use the configured destination service, you need to create an instance of it. This service is crucial when your application needs to interact with remote systems, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud, on-premise systems, or third-party APIs.

The destination service is bound to you app so that it can access the destination definition.

What happens behind the scene?

When you bind the Destination Service to your app:

  • BTP injects the credentials into your app's environment as VCAP_SERVICES

  • Your app code can use a destination name to resolve:

    • The target URL 

    • Authentication method (Basic, OAuth2, etc.)

    • Proxy type (Internet or OnPremise)

If you are connecting to an on-premise system, it routes through SAP Cloud Connector.

How to create a service in BTP?

  • Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit
  • Navigate to your subaccount → Cloud Foundry environment → Space.
  • Go to the Services -> Instances section.
  • Click Create Instance.
  • Choose a Service (e.g.:
    • "Destination" for Destination Service
    • "Connectivity" for accessing on-premise systems
    • "xsuaa" for user authentication/authorization
    • "hana-cloud" or postgresql for databases
  • Choose a plan (e.g. lite, standard, etc.)
  • Enter the name
  • Click Create.

                                               Fig 25. Create a service

Alternatively you can also create a service using bash command as below:

cf create-service destination lite service_name_001 #Replace with your service name

Once the coding is complete, you can proceed with testing the functionality.

Using terminal login to cloud foundry, use the command

cf login

                                           Fig 26. Login to CF

Once the login is successful you will see the below message

                                                Fig 27. CF login

After which you can deploy your app using the below command

cf push

Once the app is deployed navigate to the cloud foundry -> your space -> your app, get the application routes url for testing.

Use,

  • application_routes_url/   
  • application_routes_url/fetch_data 
  • application_routes_url/update_data

Test results

Home page

                          Fig 28. Home page

Fetch Data

                                      Fig 29. Fetch data via OData

Conclusion

Integrating SAP BTP with SAP S/4HANA Cloud using the Destination Service and SAP Cloud Connector provides a secure and scalable way to extend your enterprise systems into the cloud. In this blog, we explored how to configure the necessary services, set up destinations, and connect a cloud application to S/4HANA Cloud to fetch and modify Purchase Order data using OData APIs.

Whether you're building a full-stack application or a lightweight service to automate business processes, understanding the role of Destination Service and Cloud Connector is critical to securely bridging the gap between your cloud apps and backend systems. This approach not only enhances flexibility but also ensures your architecture stays modular, maintainable, and cloud-ready.

I hope this blog serves as a helpful starting point for anyone new to SAP BTP and Destination service. Stay tuned for more hands-on insights and real-world examples from my journey with agentic use cases and enterprise integration!

entry.content:
Hello SAP community, my name is Gerben Blom, Field CTO with Redwood Software. I have been part of the SAP community for the last 2 decades support the Redwood partnership with SAP and our joint customer base. I am very exited with the recent developments in our partnership where we started to explore the strength of our combined product developments to enable the best outcomes in their business processes. In this blog post we will explain how the Redwood workload automation engine can be used with Joule Studio to simplify the access to backend processes and information for the business user leveraging Joule.

Introduction

For over twenty years, Redwood Software has partnered with SAP to help customers automate their most complex and mission-critical processes. RunMyJobs by Redwood stands out as a leader in the Service Orchestration and Automation Platform  (SOAP) sector and is uniquely recognized as the only Workload Automation (WLA) solution that is an SAP-endorsed app. It offers extensive integration along with a wide array of templates and connectors that serve both established on-premises systems and modern cloud and AI-driven SAP technologies. 

SAP Premium certification strengthens RunMyJobs’ alignment with SAP’s clean core strategy. It expands SAP job scheduling without custom code or workarounds that create friction and technical debt, enabling customers to maximize their SAP investments. 

Why we jumped on Joule Studio 

When SAP introduced Joule Studio— latest SAP Build capability, that allows to create custom Joule skills for unique business needs. —we saw a fast path to embed our deep scheduling expertise directly inside SAP’s business copilot, Joule. The ambition was clear: give every planner, analyst, or other line of business practitioner instant, AI-powered answers without leaving chat. 

From Fragmented Interfaces to One-Ask Insights 

Imagine checking the status of a long, overnight Material Requirements Planning (MRP) run. Yesterday, that meant hopping between SAP screens and RunMyJobs dashboards—or logging a ticket and waiting. Today, a planner simply types: 

“What’s the status of today’s MRP run?”  

Because Joule Studio’s open, API-first design lets us wire RunMyJobs actions straight into SAP transactions and data through its easy drag-and-drop interface, Joule now calls the RunMyJobs API, pulls live data, and responds instantly in the same chat. There is no swivel chair, delay, or maze of UIs—just the clarity every SLA demands. 

See it in action here!

How the Redwood Team Built the Custom Skill

Joule Studio: An open and extensible framework built for outcomes 

Joule Studio enables partners like Redwood to expand Joule's capabilities by creating custom skills that manage system transitions behind the scenes. This approach spares users from having to navigate multiple user interfaces while ensuring reliable outcomes. Additionally, we found that with the unified governance and lifecycle management of Joule skills available before deployment, Redwood developers can confidently roll out these custom skills from the development environment into production. 

An open and extensible framework is Joule Studio’s distinct value pillar (alongside deep business grounding and built-in security and compliance). Partner integrations such as RunMyJobs by Redwood bring that pillar to life for business and user impact:

By encapsulating back-office automation as Joule skills, partners can expose complex workflows—from dispute resolution to predictive maintenance—through a single conversational interface prompt.

Conclusion and next steps

Redwood envisions a future where AI agents make Service Orchestration and Automation Platforms (SOAP) an integral part of the daily experience for business users, not just a backend tool for IT. Rather than being seen as a bolt-on to SAP systems, automation fabrics become native, empowering business users with the same speed, precision, and reliability IT teams have relied on for decades. entry.title: Amazon Seller Central SAP S4 HANA integration Part 2 - Fulfilled by Merchant
entry.content:
Banner Image - SAP S4 HANA and Amazon FBM Integration Explained.

Just incase you landed on this directly, this is a second chapter of how you can integrate SAP S4 with Amazon Seller Central if you are operating under Fulfilled by Merchant model. In the first part - How to get started with SAP S4 HANA and Amazon Seller Central integration,  I discussed how I started building SAP Integration with Amazon Seller Central. The challenges and difficulties in getting and maintaining Amazon developer ID. We also talked about various Amazon API structure and various Amazon merchant models.

Understanding Amazon FBM process using SAP S4 SAP Sales and Distribution (SD) cycle

In this post, we are going to be talking about how you can integrate Amazon in case of Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM) scenario. I assume that most of the audience here would be well versed in SAP Sales and Distribution. If you are too, FBM is a drop ship kind of arrangement with Amazon, where customers come and place an order on Amazon, the shipping happens from Merchant’s warehouse.

What is Amazon FBM Model

Amazon then settles account with Merchant on a periodic basis. If you are with me so far, you got the important gist of the process. Let me show you how you can integrate FBM process using standard SAP SD cycle.

Let us break the integration into individual components.

  • Merchandize and catalog sync
  • Inventory synchronization
  • Amazon Order syncing with SAP
  • Out going delivery and tracking number
  • Invoice generation and A/R Posting
  • Return and refunds
  • Financial reconciliation between SAP and Amazon

A. Syncing merchandise with Amazon Seller Central Account

You may be selling only a part of your offerings on Amazon. Making a neat store with a proper tree structure and products assigned to them is of course the first step in getting started.

This is often done manually. Product information is enriched with proper images, description, related items for cross sell, specifications and more. See below Apple's store on Amazon with categories neatly laid out. 

Apple's Amazon Store with Categories and Sub-Categories

A key link to SAP’s material master and Amazon’s listing is the ASIN number. There are several ways to maintain ASIN numbers within SAP.

  • Text with Material
  • Custom table
  • Customer Material Info records
  • Unused field in Material Master

Customer material info records is the the cleanest way to do so. This is so because to be able to run SD cycle, Amazon has to be created as a business partner within SAP.

Maintaining Material Information in Customer Material Info Records with ASIN Numbers

 

It must be noted that the listings must be accurate and any orders placed for an item you have discontinued and are not being able to fulfill is dealt ruthlessly by Amazon. This reflects into your ratings and also search rankings.

B. Inventory Synchronization

You have to let Amazon know how much of each ASIN you have in stock ( ATP quantity). This becomes so crucial that it can make or break your Amazon store.

Syncing ATP Quantities with Amazon is a must for FBM Merchants.

As I mention that any orders placed on Amazon, if unfulfilled by merchant brings you down several notches and gives your closest competitor to rank above you.

Remember that SAP is your system of records. All B2B, EDI, Direct to Consumer orders being fulfilled centrally from the application. Each B2B order can change ATP across SKUs considerably.

So in essence, there are only two ways to deal with this situation.

  • Highly efficient integration which updates the inventory quantities several times a day.
  • Creating a separate plant or storage location exclusively for Amazon orders.

Another dimension to inventory sync is multi location stock.

If your inventory is spread across multiple warehouses in different regions, it’s best to sync these stock levels to Amazon. Amazon uses its intelligence then to calculate the estimated delivery time when customer sees the product. Receiving the product in 6 days versus 2, could be the single deciding factor for him to place order to browse other merchants.

 

C. Syncing Amazon FBM orders into SAP S4

The single most important aspect of this sync for all merchants is getting Amazon FBM Orders into their ERP, as efficiently as possible. This helps them get a window to be able to pick pack and ship the goods from the respective warehouse and let Amazon know the shipping details. 

In my experience working with several Amazon customers, a successful and optimized Amazon order in SAP should have the following key elements.

  • Amazon Order Number - I use PO number field for the same.
  • Shipping address - This not only ensures accurate shipping but also correct tax calculation. Remember that Amazon collects the tax on your behalf and it should match SAP’s calculation.
  • Bill to - This will be always Amazon for you.
  • Amazon Fees and Charges - You should have each Amazon fees and charges at the line item as mapped conditions type. Remember that some condition type can be statistical. For example the tax Amazon collected. If you do this part correct, the net amount payable by Amazon will match what it shows on your Amazon merchant portal. This I would say is the litmus test for orders synced.

Amazon Fees and Charges must be mapped to Condition Types within orders for better concilliation

  • Product and Quantities - Each ASIN must be converted to respective material numbers.

Litmus Test for Amazon Order Synced with SAP is that Net Amount must match what it shows as Payable on Amazon Portal

D. Outgoing Delivery and Tracking details

Amazon orders being shipped out of warehouse are usually small parcels. When PGI is done for these orders, tracking number should be related back to Amazon. Amazon notifies the end customer about the shipping details.

Amazon expects high operational efficiency from the merchants, specially the ones under FBM model.

Shipping goods as early as possible is really important for FBM Merchants

Hence, orders must ideally be shipped the same day, or even better within few hours.

This again calls for efficient and bi-directional integration.

While merchants may ship the goods in a timely manner, they are responsible for a timely delivery too. Hence any carrier delay also affects them adversely.

While this may seem unfair, there is a solution which Amazon offers around this. Amazon Veeqo is Amazon’s new acquisition which helps FBM merchant reduce their shipping cost as well as de risk them from carrier delays. Hence if a FBM merchant use Veeqo, any carrier delay doesn’t affect their ratings.

Bill of Lading is a good placeholder for storing tracking number for Outgoing Deliveries

E. Invoice

Interestingly, vendor invoice is not something Amazon is interested in getting. However for completeness of the process, merchants need to post SD Invoice when then post accurate receivables.

F. Return and Refunds

Amazon’s customer service and return policies are exceptional. When a customer returns goods, merchants need to raise a RMA. When goods are received at their end, Amazon issues them a credit.

In this case, a return order must be created in SAP with an inbound delivery and Post Goods Return followed by credit memo. The amount must match the respective line item in the original order.

G. Payment reconciliation

Amazon usually has a 2 week settlement cycle. This is amount paid for 2 week of sales net of returns. Given the volume of transactions, it becomes difficult to do it manually. A payment reconciliation report like the one below ease this entire process.

Why your Amazon settlement looks different from A/R shown in SAP

Despite doing the above integration, you may still find some differences in the amount you expected versus what Amazon paid you. This is so because there are some non order related, account level charges that may have been applied.

Some of them include any promotional event that you may have run with Amazon. Amazon also keeps a margin, some sort of deposit for every merchant. This margin safeguards Amazon to fulfill its commitment to customers on case merchant goes out of business. The margin amount d fluctuates as business transaction grows and hence adjustment may be required.

A few manual Adjustments may be needed despite integration

The good thing is that this is not usual or monthly phenomenon. Also these can be adjusted with few manual postings.

Without integration this entire reconciliation becomes manual and tedious.

Frequently asked questions

Here are some frequently asked questions regarding FBM questions in general and its integration with SAP in particular.

1. What is FBM and how is it different from FBA?

FBM stands for Fulfilled by Merchant. In this model, you (the seller) are responsible for storing, packing, and shipping the products when a customer places an order on Amazon.
On the other hand, FBA (Fulfilled by Amazon) means Amazon takes care of storing and shipping your products from its own warehouses.

2. How does the integration process differ for FBM?

In FBM, since the seller handles fulfillment, the integration focuses on syncing orders, inventory, deliveries, tracking details, and payment reconciliation between Amazon and SAP. You’re also expected to respond quickly to new orders and keep inventory up to date to avoid penalties from Amazon.

3. Is the integration approach different between SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC?

The core logic remains similar, but S/4HANA offers improved capabilities—like better data structures and more streamlined APIs—which can make the integration smoother. However, both require proper mapping of orders, products (ASINs), and financial data.

4. Can I consolidate Amazon orders into a single SAP order?

It’s not recommended. Each Amazon order should be created as a separate sales order in SAP. This ensures better tracking, accurate taxation, shipping, and proper return/refund processing.

5. Why is financial reconciliation so important?

Even after syncing all the order details, Amazon might deduct fees or hold a margin at the account level. Without regular reconciliation between Amazon reports and SAP receivables, these mismatches can cause accounting issues and missed revenue.

6. What is Amazon Veeqo and how can it help FBM sellers?

Veeqo is a shipping and inventory tool by Amazon, especially useful for FBM sellers. It helps reduce shipping costs and protects your account ratings from delays caused by third-party carriers. If the delay is on the courier side and you’re using Veeqo, Amazon won’t penalize you.

7. What is multi-location inventory and why is it important?

If you store inventory across different warehouses, syncing stock levels with Amazon helps customers see more accurate delivery timelines. For example, a buyer may prefer a seller who can deliver in 2 days versus 6. This improves chances of making a sale.

8. How do I link my SAP materials to Amazon listings?

You need to match each product’s ASIN (Amazon Standard Identification Number) with its corresponding Material Number in SAP. The cleanest way to do this is by using Customer Material Info Records in SAP, especially if Amazon is set up as a customer in your system.

9. How often should inventory be synced with Amazon?

Ideally, multiple times a day. Amazon expects real-time inventory updates to avoid overselling. If that's hard to manage, you could also dedicate a separate plant or storage location for Amazon orders to simplify tracking and syncing.

10. Do I need to send invoices to Amazon?

No, Amazon doesn’t ask for your invoices. But you still need to create and post invoices in SAP so your books are accurate and receivables are tracked properly.

11. What happens if I can’t fulfill an Amazon order?

Amazon is strict about fulfillment. If you fail to ship an order, your ratings and rankings take a hit—which can reduce your visibility and sales. That’s why tight integration and up-to-date inventory are critical.

12. How are returns and refunds handled in SAP?

When a customer returns a product, Amazon issues a credit. On your end, you should create a return order in SAP, do the Post Goods Receipt, and generate a credit memo—all while matching the original order details to keep records clean.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower: Q2 2025 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the first half of 2025, global sustainability governance has entered a new phase of scrutiny and recalibration. The EU Omnibus amendments to the CSRD have postponed timelines and reduced the scope of immediate obligations for thousands of companies, temporarily easing the pressure of compliance. However, this regulatory pause has only sharpened the spotlight on data integrity, preparedness, and strategic ESG integration. 

At the same time, investors, regulators, and civil society are intensifying their expectations. Public disclosures are no longer judged on completeness alone—they must be audit-ready, aligned with recognized frameworks like ESRS and EU Taxonomy. Companies are expected to move beyond box-ticking compliance into continuous ESG performance management, proactively steering their sustainability journey. 

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) is designed precisely for this challenge. It enables organizations to: 

  • Record ESG factors with out-of-the-box integration to SAP systems and trusted third-party sources 
  • Analyze performance across financial, operational, and sustainability dimensions to support informed decisions 
  • Accelerate the transition through auditable, framework-aligned reporting—covering both regulatory and voluntary disclosures, powered by AI 

Building on our momentum from Q1, this quarter's updates focus on strengthening ESRS-aligned metric coverage, deeper analytical flexibility, improved auditability, and tighter alignment with financial structures. 

 

Expansion of SAP-provided metric coverage   

To support organizations on their ESRS compliance journey, SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) continues to expand its library of SAP-provided metrics aligned with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards. These include both qualitative and quantitative definitions based on EFRAG's implementation guidance. Current metric coverage is available in the SAP Help Portal and detailed in the SAP Community blog, offering transparency and reuse for accelerated implementation.  

 

Looking ahead, we plan to reach approximately 80% coverage of ESRS data points by the end of 2025, including metrics from ESRS 2, S2–S4, G1, and additional quantitative metrics from ESRS Topical Standards. This roadmap aims to enable our customers to progressively adopt SCT content for structured, auditable, and regulation-ready ESG disclosures while maintaining flexibility to extend for sector-specific or company-specific needs. 

 

Analyze ESG Data App Enhancements 

The Analyze ESG Data application now offers a significantly improved analytics experience with the introduction of the Analytics tab. Users can explore all standard custom quantitative metrics in greater depth by applying drill-down dimensions, choosing between chart or table formats, and configuring default views tailored to reporting needs. This new flexibility allows up to three charts to be displayed simultaneously, each with independent metric, period, and structure settings. 

In parallel, users can manage and switch between saved configurations of grouped metric tiles (“Overviews”), enabling different perspectives for different stakeholders or strategic priorities. Together, these enhancements empower users to personalize and streamline how ESG data is analyzed, viewed, and shared – supporting more informed decision-making and stronger alignment with sustainability goals. Find full details here: Using the Analyze ESG Data Application.

 

Custom Templates for “Generate ESG Reports with AI” App 

The Generate ESG Reports with AI app now offers greater flexibility and control through the introduction of custom templates. Users can create or edit templates to tailor the structure and content of ESG reports using available SAP-provided quantitative metrics.  

Within the Templates section, you can now select “Create” to build a new template or modify an existing one by adding sections and subsections, defining narrative text, and selecting from a predefined list of charts and tables. For each component, a content preview is available to ensure alignment with the selected reporting period. Once finalized, templates can be saved and reused, enabling consistent and structured ESG reporting across time periods.  

When generating a report, you can preview or download the result as a PDF—and for added customization, you can edit any section manually. SAP's built-in AI-assistance now supports dynamic revisions: simply select a passage and use the “Revise” option to receive suggestions to shorten or lengthen the text, helping refine your final ESG narrative with ease and speed. 

 

Fiscal Period Support 

The new Manage Fiscal Year Variants app brings flexible fiscal period support to SAP Sustainability Control Tower, allowing customers to define and activate custom fiscal year variants that align with their internal planning cycles. Whether using standard calendar months or granular date-based periods (like semi-monthly ranges), organizations can now tailor their ESG data analysis and reporting across key apps such as Analyze ESG Data, Manage GHG Data, and View Emission Dashboard. Built-in validation checks help ensure data compatibility, with options to consolidate or reimport data when switching to a new variant. This enables more accurate reporting, tighter alignment with financial periods, and greater control over how sustainability data is structured and interpreted across the organization. 

 

Change log updates 

In Q2, we've significantly improved transparency and traceability across SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT). Users can now track create, update, and delete changes to public overview configurations in the Analyze ESG Data app using the View Change Logs app. This functionality extends further, providing detailed logs for changes in business activity data, clearly showing the number of updated or imported records and distinguishing between actual and target data. 

 

New Languages Supported 

To better serve global enterprises, SAP SCT now supports Turkish and Italian languages. This update enables local teams to work in their native languages and enhances cross-regional collaboration on sustainability data collection and reporting. 

 

H2 2025 Roadmap Updates 

Looking ahead, we’re focused on simplifying and harmonizing ESG data consumption and reporting. A key milestone will be the delivery of a unified Read API for metric values – supporting both quantitative and qualitative data – to  make calculated ESG metrics easily accessible to external tools like disclosure management platforms. This API will also expose key metadata (including ESG standard references) and allow for both bulk and individual metric retrieval based on reporting scopes. We’re also working on improving flexibility in data modeling by enabling custom account groups, account-to-group mappings, and supporting activity data input through multiple channels. Additionally, we’ll continue expanding metric-level analysis, measure drilldowns, and export formats in the Analyze ESG data application. To enhance data quality and reporting alignment, we’re introducing tools for guiding data requirements based on double materiality, setting up reporting hierarchies and data sources, and improving transparency on data completeness. In parallel, we aim to deliver ESRS-aligned metric definitions that cover up to 70% of EFRAG's guidance, along with clear documentation and community updates to keep you informed as mentioned above. Stay tuned: SCT Roadmap Explorer. 

 

Additional Information 

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Control Tower, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.
